Our friend has had to struggle for a long time on her own to help her family get ahead in life. This is why she has a home business selling diapers.  She also has a taxi which her husband used to drive, until he passed away. Now a driver operates it, to whom she pays a weekly salary. 

She says that it's been very hard to move forward, but thanks to God her children are now grown up and can manage on their own. She says that thanks to the loans she has been able to overcome very difficult situations in her life. 

She is going to use this loan in her two businesses. She is going to buy diapers, and two tires for the taxi. Her dream is to keep moving forward in life and to enjoy good health.

loans.use: To buy tires and diapers.

loans.name: Irene Jaqueline

texts.es:
EL Banco Comunal Bienestar y Progreso que se reúne cada quince días en Colorado del Cantón Montecristi , conocido por su rica cultura pre colonial y por su artesanía a nivel nacional e internacional. Lugar de los famosos sombreros de paja toquilla.

Aquí conocimos a Irene, tiene 36 años  de edad, está soltera y  vive en casa de sus padres. Esta desde el inicio en el Banco Comunal, es la tesorera del banco  y le gusta porque son muy unidas en el grupo.

Ella trabaja en el INFA (Instituto Ecuatoriano de la Niñez y la Familia) pero además de esto también tiene un negocio propio, ella vende ropa de todo tipo en su casa donde tiene un local el cual le ayuda a atender su mamá,  también vende en el trabajo ya que eso no le quita mayor tiempo, lleva dos años con su negocio y le ha ido bastante bien. Su mercadería se la envían desde New York por lo cual sus clientes cada vez que llega mercadería le piden que les muestre sus productos.
 
Este crédito es para pagar una mercadería que está por llegar como: pantalones, camisetas y ropa de niños que es lo que más vende.
 
Sus sueños son seguir trabajando y aumentar su negocio.
texts.en:
The Bienestar y Progreso ["Well-Being and Progress"] Communal Bank meets every fifteen days in Colorado, in the Montecristi canton. The region is nationally and internationally known for its rich pre-colonial culture and for its artistry. It is the home of the famous straw hats.

Here we meet Irene. She is 36, single, and lives in her parents' home. She has been the treasurer since the beginning of the Communal Bank, and she likes it because the group is very united.

She works at INFA (Instituto Ecuatoriano de la Niñez y la Familia: Ecuadorian Institution for Childhood and the Family), but on top of this she also has a small business of her own. She sells all kinds of clothing in her home, where she has a shop which her mother helps her to tend. She also sells at work because this does not take up extra time. She has had her business for two years and it has gone very well for her. She gets her merchandise from New York, so every time it arrives her customers ask her to show them her products.

This loan is to pay for a pending order of items such as: pants, shirts and children's clothing, which is what she sells the most.

Her dreams are to continue working and to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase pants, shirts and children's clothing.

loans.name: Mercedes Migdalia

texts.es:
EL Banco Comunal Bienestar y Progreso que se reúne cada quince días en Colorado del Cantón Montecristi , conocido por su rica cultura pre colonial y por su artesanía a nivel nacional e internacional. Lugar de los famosos sombreros de paja toquilla.

Aquí conocimos a la señora Mercedes tiene 48 años  de edad, es madre soltera de  una hija de  17 años de edad la misma que estudia en colegio. Ella vive en casa de sus padres. Esta desde el inicio  en el Banco Comunal y le gusta  por los créditos y porque el grupo es muy unido.

Nuestra amiga trabaja de secretaria y contadora en una cooperativa de taxis, además tiene un taxi propio el cual lo hace conducir por un chofer a quien le paga un sueldo semanal,  tiene su taxi por seis años y fue con el primer crédito que pago parte de la entrada y que con los créditos siguientes a podido acabarlo de pagar y por fin es la propietaria del mismo con el que puede salir adelante y darle una vida digna a su hija.

Este crédito es para comprar repuestos para el taxi.
 
Su sueño es comprar otro carro para hacerlo trabajar como taxi.
texts.en:
The Bienestar y Progreso ["Well-Being and Progress"] communal bank meets every fifteen days in Colorado, in the Montecristi canton. This area is known nationally and internationally for its rich pre-colonial culture and for its artistry. It is the home of the famous straw hats.

Here we meet Mrs. Mercedes. She is 48, and a single mother of a 17-year-old daughter who is in school. Mercedes lives in her parents' home. She has been part of the communal bank from the beginning, and she likes it because of the loans and because the group is very united.

Our friend works as a secretary and an accountant in a taxi cooperative. She also has her own taxi and she pays a driver a weekly salary to drive it. She has had her taxi for six years, and her first loan paid for part of the deposit. With her subsequent loans she was able to pay it off and she is finally the owner of the taxi. With it, she can get ahead and provide her daughter with a decent life.

This loan is for purchasing spare parts for the taxi.

Her dream is to buy another car to work as a taxi.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts for the taxi.

loans.name: Angelita

texts.en:
Angelita, a 44-year-old married mother of one, lives in Purok 2 Carangan, Ozamiz City where she has had a shop that sells a variety of dry goods and peanut butter for the past six years.

Angelita has requested a loan for 40,000 PHP to purchase dry goods for her business and ingredients for her peanut butter. A member of PMPC for four years, she hopes to improve her living conditions in the future.

loans.use: to purchase dry goods for her business and ingredients for her peanut butter.

loans.name: Jecil

texts.en:
Jecil is married with one child. Jecil is 22 years old and lives in the Philippines. 

Jecil is a farmer and raises pigs to earn a living. She has been doing this for two years. She has requested a loan of PHP 14,900 to buy two piglets and feed. 

She has been a member of PMPC for two years. In the future, Jecil hopes to be successful in her chosen business.

loans.use: to purchase two piglets and feed

loans.name: Karen Juliana

texts.es:
EL Banco Comunal Bienestar y Progreso que se reúne cada quince días en Colorado del Cantón Montecristi , conocido por su rica cultura pre colonial y por su artesanía a nivel nacional e internacional. Lugar de los famosos sombreros de paja toquilla.

Aquí conocimos a Karen, tiene 22 años  de edad, está soltera y  vive en casa de sus padres, estudia el octavo semestre de periodismo en la Universidad Laica de Manta.

Además de dedicarse a sus estudios nuestra amiga se dedica al comercio, vende productos de Yanbal, Avon y Sayson (productos de belleza, cosméticos, perfumería y accesorios para damas). Trabaja todos días ya que además de vender por el lugar donde vive también vende en la universidad a sus compañeras de clases y conocidos, deja sus productos a crédito y cobra cada quince días. Tiene tres años que se dedica a esta actividad y le va muy bien, lo que más vende son las cremas ya que son muy buenas.

Este crédito es para comprar perfumes, cremas, cosméticos y bisutería. Lleva dos años en el Banco Comunal y le gusta porque los créditos son rápidos.

Sus sueños son terminar sus estudios y tener un buen trabajo.
texts.en:
The Bienestar y Progreso ["Well-Being and Progress"] Communal Bank meets every fifteen days in Colorado, in the Montecristi canton. This region is known nationally and internationally for its rich pre-colonial culture and artistry. This is the home of the famous straw hats.

Here we meet Karen. She is 22, single, and lives in her parents' home. She is in her eighth semester of journalism at the Universidad Laica de Manta.

On top of her studies, our friend is a merchant. She sells Yanbal, Avon and Sayson products (beauty products, perfume and women's accessories). She works every day, since on top of selling in her neighbourhood, she also sells at the university to her classmates and acquaintances. She leaves her products on credit and charges every fifteen days. She has done this work for three years and it is going very well for her. Her biggest sellers are the creams, because they are very good.

This loan is for purchasing perfumes, creams, cosmetics and costume jewellery. She has been a member of the communal bank for two years and she likes it because the loans are fast.

Her dreams are to complete her studies and have a good job.

loans.use: to purchase perfumes, creams, cosmetics and costume jewellery.

loans.name: Rafaela Dalila

texts.es:
EL Banco Comunal Bienestar y Progreso que se reúne cada quince días en Colorado del Cantón Montecristi , conocido por su rica cultura pre colonial y por su artesanía a nivel nacional e internacional. Lugar de los famosos sombreros de paja toquilla.

En este lugar vive la señora Rafaela, tiene 43  años de edad y mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene dos hijos de 10 y 8 años de edad, ellos estudian en escuela. El marido es mecánico automotriz.
 
Es un ama de casa que para obtener sus propios recursos se dedica a la venta de ropa de todo tipo y productos de Yanbal (productos de belleza, cosméticos, perfumería y accesorios para damas). Su forma de venta es puerta a puerta,  trabaja cuatro días a la semana más que todo por las mañanas ya que a esa hora sus hijos están en la escuela y puede realizar sus recorridos con más comodidad, deja sus productos a crédito y cobra cada semana. Tiene cuatro años que se dedica a esta actividad y le va muy bien, su mercadería la compra en Quito.

Este crédito es para comprar perfumes, cremas, cosméticos, pantalones, blusas, entre otras prendas de vestir. Lleva cuatro años  en el Banco Comunal y le gusta porque con el primer crédito empezó su negocio que hoy le da muchas ganancias. 

Su sueño es tener una boutique.
texts.en:
The Bienestar y Progreso ["Well-Being and Progress"] Communal Bank meets every fifteen days in Colorado, in the Montecristi canton. This region is known nationally and internationally for its rich pre-colonial culture and for its artistry. This area is the home of the famous straw hats.

Rafaela lives in this area. She is 43 and in a common-law marriage from which she has two children, ages 8 and 10. They are in school. Her husband is an automotive mechanic.

She is a housewife who, in order to make her own income, sells all types of clothing as well as Yanbal products (beauty products, cosmetics, perfumes and women's accessories). She sells door-to-door. She works four days a week, mainly in the mornings, because her children are in school at that time and she can more easily do her work. She leaves her products on credit, and charges every week. She has done this for four years and it is going very well for her. She buys her merchandise in Quito.

This loan is to purchase perfumes, creams, cosmetics, pants, blouses, and other items of clothing. She has been in the Communal Bank for four years and she likes it because she started her business, which now gives her great earnings, with her first loan.

Her dream is to have a boutique.

loans.use: to purchase perfumes, creams, cosmetics, pants, blouses and other clothing garments.

loans.name: Glenda Giomar

texts.es:
EL Banco Comunal Bienestar y Progreso que se reúne cada quince días en Colorado del Cantón Montecristi , conocido por su rica cultura pre colonial y por su artesanía a nivel nacional e internacional. Lugar de los famosos sombreros de paja toquilla.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Glenda, tiene 50 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen tres hijos todos mayores de edad pero aun vive con ella. Su esposo es chofer profesional.

Es una ama de casa que para obtener sus propios recursos se dedica a la venta de productos naturales de la marca Garden y de productos de Yanbal (productos de belleza, cosméticos, perfumería y accesorios para damas). Su forma de venta es puerta a puerta, Trabaja tres días a la semana, deja sus productos a crédito y cobra cada quince días. Tiene seis años que se dedica a esta actividad y empezó con el primer crédito que recibió del banco.

Este crédito es para comprar perfumes, cremas, cosméticos y productos naturales. Esta 6 años  en el Banco Comunal y le gusta porque los pagos son fáciles de hacer.
 
Sus sueños son seguir adelante en su negocio creciendo dia a dia.
texts.en:
The Bienestar y Progreso ["Well-Being and Progress"] Communal Bank meets every fifteen days in Colorado, in the Montecristi canton. This region is known nationally and internationally for its rich pre-colonial culture and artistry. It is the home of the famous straw hats.

Here we meet Mrs. Glenda. She is 50, married, and has three children. They are all grown but still live with her. Her husband is a professionnal driver.
She is a housewife who, in order to make her own income, sells Garden natural products and Yanbal products (beauty products: cosmetics, perfumes and women's accessories). She sells door-to-door. She works three days a week. She leaves her products on credit and charges every fifteen days. She has done this for six years and started it with her first loan, which she took out from a bank.

This loan is to purchase perfumes, creams, cosmetics and natural products. She has been in the Communal Bank for 6 years, and she likes it because the payments are easy to make.

Her dreams are to continue moving forward with her business, growing every day.

loans.use: to purchase perfumes, creams, cosmetics and natural products.

loans.name: Violeta

texts.en:
Violeta is married with four children. Violeta is 53 years old and lives in Gango, Ozamiz City.

Violeta sells malagkit snacks or sticky rice snacks, locally known as biko, to earn a living and has had this business for three years. She earns PHP 3,000 each month from this business. She has requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to purchase two sacks of sticky rice.

Violeta has been a member of PMPC for almost one year. In the future, Violeta hopes to be successful in her business.

loans.use: to purchase two sacks of sticky rice

loans.name: Mylen

texts.en:
Mylen is 31 years old and married with 3 children. With 3 children in school, Mylen works very hard to provide for them.

Mylen runs a ready-to-wear sandals and clothes business in the Philippines and requested a PHP 19000 loan through NWTF to buy more products.

Mylen has been in this business for 3 years.

In the future Mylen would like to build and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more products for her ready-to-wear business.

loans.name: Petronila

texts.en:
As a married parent of 9 children, Petronila works hard to support her family.

She has a food vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from pig fattening.  Petronila is borrowing PHP 25000 through NWTF to purchase more bananas for her food vending business.

Petronila has been sustaining her business activities through her past 9 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: To purchase more bananas for her business.

loans.name: Mayra Mirtala

texts.es: Mayra Mirtala tiene 34 años de edad, es una persona alegre y laboriosa, se dedica al cultivo de cafe, es casada, tiene tres hijos de los cuales dos son varones, y junto a su familia reside en la Comunidad de Las Vegas en el Municipio de Trojes. Comenzo a cultivar cafe desde el año 93, y lo aprendio de sus padres. La jornada laboral en la finca de cafe inicia desde las 6:00 am y culmina a las 12:00 pm, y cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo y de algunos trabajadores. Mayra tambien tiene una pequeña pulperia en su casa de habitacion y sus hijos se turnan para ayudar a atenderla, ella decidio incursionar en el negocio de venta de abarroteria ya que los ingresos que le dejaba el cultivo de cafe no eran suficientes para cubrir los gastos del hogar y del estudio de sus hijos. Actualmente Mayra no tiene mayor dificultades para el sostenimiento de su familia y se siente muy agradecida con Dios y con el apoyo recibido por medio de los prestamos otorgados por FAMA. El prestamo solicitado lo necesita para comprar fertilizantes y asi poder fertilizar las 7 mz de tierra del cultivo de cafe. Con el apoyo del prestamo su produccion sera de mayor calidad y podra venderla a un mejor precio. Su meta es seguir manteniendo sus negocios activos y seguir incursionando en otros, tambien seguirle dando humildemente a su familia una mejor condicion de vida. Este es su tercer ciclo en FAMA y espera cumplir con su compromiso de pagos de forma puntual.
texts.en: Mayra Mirtala is 34 years old.  She is a happy and hard-working person who makes her living growing coffee.  She is married and has three children, two of whom are boys.  Together with her family, she lives in the Las Vegas community in the municipality of Trojes.  Mayra began growing coffee in 1993; she learned the skill from her parents.  The workday on the farm starts at 6:00am and finishes at 12:00pm.  She has the help of her husband and some workers.  Mayra also runs a small grocery from her home.  Her children trade off helping her with the customers.  Mayra decided to get into the grocery business because her earnings from coffee growing weren't enough to cover the household expenses and her children's schooling.  Mayra does not currently have any major difficulties supporting her family.  She feels very grateful to god and thankful for the financial help she has been granted through FAMA.  Mayra needs the requested loan to purchase fertilizers to be able to fertilize the roughly 12 acres of land she has planted with coffee.  With the help of the loan, she will have better quality production and will be able to sell at a better price.  Mayra's goal is to keep her businesses active and to continue getting into other businesses.  She also wants to continue to humbly give her family a better quality of life.  This is Mayra's third cycle with FAMA and she plans to punctually comply with her re-payment schedule.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer for her coffee crop.

loans.name: Ma. Luisa

texts.en:
Ma. Luisa works hard to support five children. She is married and has a buying and selling of corn business in the Philippines.

Ma. Luisa requested a PHP 1,800 loan through NWTF to buy an ENVIROFIT COOKSTOVE.

She is getting the envirofit cookstove because she wants to save money by using the dried wood she can pick up from her surroundings.

Ma. Luisa is aware that by using the envirofit cookstove, she is not only saving money, she is also helping the environment and reducing health and hazard risks to her family.

loans.use: To purchase a cookstove

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
Rosalie, who is married, works hard to support three children by selling bicycle spare parts in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 1800 loan through NWTF to buy an ENVIROFIT COOKSTOVE because she wants to save money by using the dried wood she can pick from her surroundings as fuel.

Rosalie is aware that by using the envirofit cookstove, she will not only be saving money, but also helping the environment and reducing health and hazard risks to her family.

loans.use: to purchase an envirofit cookstove.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan works hard to support 5 children. She is married and has a sari-sari store in the Philippines.

Susan requested a PHP 1800 loan through NWTF to buy an ENVIROFIT COOKSTOVE.  She is getting the Envirofit stove because she wants to save money by using the dried wood she can pick form her surroundings.  Susan is aware that by using the Envirofit stove, she is not only saving money, she is also helping the environment and reducing health and hazard risks to her family.

loans.use: To purchase Envirofit cookstove

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Edna works hard to support her family.

She has a furniture making business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from livestock & a restaurant. Edna is borrowing PHP 14,000 through NWTF to purchase materials for her furniture-making business.

Edna has been sustaining her business activities through her past three loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream: to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase materials for furniture making.

loans.name: Guidelyn

texts.en:
Guidelyn is 29 years old and has two children. Guidelyn is married and her two children are in school. She is in the agricultural business raising livestock in the Philippines. Guidelyn requested a PHP 16,000 loan through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her livestock.

Guidelyn has been raising livestock for four years now and has borrowed three times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

In the future, Guidelyn would like to repair and renovate her family home.

loans.use: To buy feed and vitamins for her livestock.

loans.name: Jesusa

texts.en:
Jesusa is 29 years old and married with three children.

Jesusa works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari (variety) store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc. 

Jesusa has borrowed and repaid two loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for two years and also earns an income from feed retailing, selling ready-to-wear clothes, farming sugarcane, buying and selling used clothes and  selling electronic reloads.

Jesusa aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: To buy items to sell.

loans.name: Pacita

texts.en:
Pacita, a 53-year-old married mother of nine, has been earning a living by farming vegetables in the Philippines for the past four years. She earns additional income by buying and selling livestock.

Pacita is borrowing PHP 15000 through NWTF to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies, and is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream of building and expanding her business in order to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy fertilzers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Marcela

texts.en:
Marcela is 45 years old and married with five children.

Marcela works hard to provide for her family. She runs a variety store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 17,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more items to sell in her variety store.

Marcela has borrowed and re-paid 16 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the variety store for 3 years and also earns an income from food vending.

Marcela aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more items to sell in her variety store

loans.name: Miguela

texts.en: Miguela works hard to support her family. Miguela is married and has a food vending business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 10 years. Miguela requested a 12,000 Philippine peso loan through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food production business. Miguela would like to expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business

loans.name: Nelia

texts.en: Nelia is single and has a business buying and selling home products in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 10 years. Nelia works hard to support her family. She requested a 12,000 Philippine peso loan through NWTF to purchase more home products to sell. Nelia would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more home products to sell

loans.name: Nimfa

texts.en: As a married parent of seven children, Nimfa works hard to support her family. She has a carinderia (local eatery) business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from a sari-sari store. Nimfa is borrowing 15,000 PHP through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food production business. Nimfa has been sustaining her business activities with her past four loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of expanding her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business

loans.name: Jeanny

texts.en:
Jeanny is 29 years old and from Clarin, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. She is a single lady who has been able to manage corn production. It was hard for Jeanny at first to cope with it, but by and by, she got to love it.  Now she is interested in doing the job assigned. She has been told by her parents to manage the agricultural business of the family in order to practice and enhance her skills in running a business.   A successful entrepreneur starts small. Every month, she gets an estimated total of PHP 10,000.

Earlier this year, Jeanny joined GDMPC to be able to use financial services. Her first loan of PHP 12,000 will be used to compensate labor costs for weeding and for the purchase of some fertilizers. She expects to reap a good harvest and will invest in business expansion from the expected revenue to be generated.

loans.use: To pay for labor costs for weeding and to buy some fertilizers.

loans.name: Jessel

texts.en:
Jessel is from Clarin, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. She is 35 years old and is married.  She takes good care of her 3 school-aged children. Jessel owns a two-wheeled motorcycle to transport passengers. The motorcycle has the capacity to carry 2-4 persons to certain destinations. Over two years, Jessel's good management has made her stand out.  At the end of the month, she gets PHP 9,000 which she uses for day-to-day expenditures and on other wants as well.

This year, 2011, Jessel joined GDMPC to have use of financial services. She has applied for PHP 10,000 to purchase motorcycle accessories to improve the service's appearance. Keeping the motorcycle in good running condition brings in good income for the family. Jessel hopes to get adequate income from this investment so she can buy a side car to expand seating capacity of the motorcycle.

loans.use: To purchase motorcycle accessories to improve the service's appearance.

loans.name: Gerry

texts.en:
Gerry, a resident of Clarin, Misamis Occidental, Philippines, is 34 years old, married, and operates his own two-wheeled motorcycle to earn a living for the past year. His service has the capacity to transport up to four passengers to their designated destinations, earning him approximately PHP 10,000 each month,

Gerry joined GDMPC earlier this year to gain access to financial services. He is now requesting a loan of PHP 10,000 to purchase a motor headlight and other spare parts for better service. When he gets enough funds, he will buy a vacant lot for farming in order to earn more income.

loans.use: to purchase a motor headlight and other spare parts for better service.

loans.name: Roberta

texts.en:
Roberta is married with five children.  She is 52 years old and has one child who is still in school.  She is a very hard working entrepreneur.

Roberta has a fishing business in the Philippines.  She requested a PHP 11,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase fishing gear and equipment.

Roberta has been in this business for 15 years.  She would like to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase fishing gear and equipment

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
Theresa is 37 years old and married with 4 children.  With 3 children in school, Theresa works very hard to provide for them.

She runs a sari-sari store (variety store) in the Philippines and requested a PHP 18,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional items to sell in her store.

Theresa has been in this business for 10 years and sells a variety of items such as snack foods, noodles, and other miscellaneous products. 

In the future Theresa would like to build and expand her business in order to support the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional items to sell in her store

loans.name: Rossana

texts.en:
Rossana is 37 years old, married and a mother of seven. She lives in Clarin, Misamis Occidental, Philippines, where growing and selling corn is her main source of income. She has been tilling the land for 18 years with her husband, earning approximately PHP 9,000 a month, which helps to meet the family's needs.

In 2008, Rossana joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services. Her previous loan repaid, she is now requesting her second one for PHP 5,000 to pay for land preparation costs to start the next cycle of production. Future revenue will be invested in land expansion and planting productive root crops, legumes, shrubs, etc.

loans.use: to pay for land preparation costs.

loans.name: Magdalina

texts.en:
Magdalina is a resident of Clarin, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. She is a 59-year-old widow with 4 adult-aged children. Magdalina has owned and operated a retail store at home for the past 3 years. It was created to answer people's day-to-day consumption. Magdalina earns approximately PHP 7,000 monthly from business operations.

Magdalina became a GDMPC member in 2006. She has taken out loans from the cooperative twice and successfully repaid them. Magdalina is now requesting a loan of PHP 8,000 to purchase daily use merchandise to sell in order to earn more income. She hopes to sustain the store's revolving funds to prolong business operations. Magdalina is planning to renovate her house so she may have a better place to live in.

loans.use: To purchase more daily use merchandise to sell.

loans.name: Amelia

texts.es: Doña Amelia tiene 54 años de edad, se dedica a la venta de abarroteria, es casada, tiene cinco hijos y un nieto, es una persona servicial aunque de caracter serio, y junto a su familia reside en la Comunidad de La Vega en el municipio de Trojes. Inicio con su pulperia hace mas de 25 años y lo aprendio empiricamente, actualmente sigue haciendolo pero ahora tambien se dedica a cultivar cafe. Con el cultivo de cafe inicio con una manzana pero ahora cuenta con seis, algunos trabajadores y su esposo la ayudan con el trabajo de la finca mientras ella atiende los quehaceres del hogar y la pulperia. La ventaja tener dos negocios es que cuenta con varias entradas de dinero y eso le permite no pasar tantas necesidades economicas, la desventaja es que la zona donde reside es cafetalera y hay varias fincas y eso limita la mano de obra. El prestamo que Doña Amelia esta solicitando lo necesita para abonar el area de cultivo y pagar la mano de obra. Con el apoyo de este prestamo su produccion dara un mejor rendimiento y podra venderla a un buen precio. Su mayor sueño para ella y su familia es mejorar su condicion de vida. Doña Amelia tiene nueve ciclos en FAMA y es una de las mejores clientes de la institucion.
texts.en:
Amelia, 54, sells groceries. She is married, has five sons and daughters, and one grandson.  She is a helpful person and very serious.  She lives with her family in La Vega community, in the town of Trojes.  She began with her grocery store more than 25 years ago and she learned by doing.  She still has the store but now she also grows coffee.  She started with one acre but now she has six.   A few laborers and her husband help her with the farm work while she takes care of the housework and the grocery store.  The advantage of having two businesses is that she can count on several sources of income and this allows her to keep up with her expenses.  The disadvantage is that where she lives is a coffee producing area with other  farms and this limits her access to farm labor.  She will use the requested loan to buy fertilizer for the fields and to pay the farmhands.  This loan will help her achieve more production and she can sell the crop at a good price.
Her greatest dream for herself and her family is to improve their standard of living.
Amelia has had nine loan cycles with FAMA and she is one of the institution’s best clients.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pay for labor

loans.name: Anabel

texts.en:
Anabel, 43 years old, is married and has 3 grown dependents. She lives in Clarin, Misamis Occidental, Philippines with her whole family. At first, her spouse was the sole income earner of the family. When the children were growing, their needs and wants were also growing. Since Anabel had to help her husband, she began selling ready-to-wear and food items. She has been running this business for sixteen years, with monthly earnings of PHP 20,000.

Anabel became a GDMPC member in 2011. She is requesting her first loan of PHP 5,000 to obtain food and ready-to-wear items to sell. These products sell easily at the retail level. The revenue to be generated from this investment is for business expansion, acquiring more supplies to offer, and maintaining the means of living.

loans.use: To obtain food and ready-to-wear items to sell.

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.en:
Beatriz is 49 years old and lives in Labinay, Ozamiz City, Philippines. She is married, with 3 dependents. Seven years ago, Beatriz installed a small piggery at home. She wakes up early in the morning to clean the animals' shelter and to bathe and feed them properly. Beatriz has cared for and sold quite a number of these domestic animals. She earns PHP 4,000 a month from all income sources.

In 2008, Beatriz joined GDMPC to have access to financial services. Her previous loan transactions have been successfully repaid. Earlier this year, Beatriz requested another loan of PHP 5,000 to purchase swine fattening to boost the pigs' health in order to have a bigger chance of selling them at a high rate. She plans to invest the future revenue by buying more piglets to raise and widening their fencing area.

loans.use: To purchase swine fattening to boost the pigs' health.

loans.name: Nenabeth

texts.en:
Nenabeth is the mother of 2 children and she has been separated from her husband for a long while. She is from Clarin, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. Besides her other means of income, Nenabeth has owned a two-wheeled motorcycle for hire for 10 years. This service has the capacity to carry 2-4 passengers. Nenabeth earns a monthly total of PHP 12,000 from all income sources.

In 2007, Nenabeth pursued her plans of joining the GDMPC cooperative. She would like to borrow PHP 5,000 to purchase motorcycle accessories to improve service quality. Nenabeth plans to use possible revenues to buy a motor cab to extend seating capacity, thereby gaining more income.

loans.use: To purchase motorcycle accessories to improve service quality.

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina is 35 years old, married and the mother of 6 school-aged children. She lives in Clarin, Misamis Occidental, Philippines where she has planted many bananas to sell and distribute in the town's market. Her business has existed for 15 years, bringing in an income of PHP 3,000 monthly, which is properly allocated to satisfy daily needs.

Earlier this year, Gina joined the GDMPC cooperative to have access to financial services. She has applied for her first loan of PHP 5,000 to buy young export-type bananas. She will sell the ripe bananas in the town's market and in adjacent communities. Gina plans to invest future revenue on business expansion and house renovations.

loans.use: To buy young export-type bananas.

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita is a 46-year-old woman living in Clarin, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. Her husband is a scrap buyer and she runs a retail store to help with the family's income. The business has been operating for 10 years, offering commonly used commodities for everyday living. The family's monthly income from all sources is PHP 7,300.

In 2009, Nenita joined GDMPC for an easy way to enjoy financial services offered by the organization.  Earlier this year, she requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to obtain additional grocery supplies such as vinegar, salt, sugar, canned goods, etc. All revenue to be generated from this investment will be allotted primarily for store expansion, in particular to buy a small-sized stock showcase to put things in order.

loans.use: To obtain additional grocery supplies to sell

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is a resident of Clarin, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. She is married and the mother of 4 grown children. Lydia has owned and operated a retail store at home for 30 years and continues serving people. She receives a total of PHP 7,300 monthly from business operations.

Lydia became a GDMPC member in 2009. She has requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to order additional stock of liquor to sell. The revenue from this investment will be used to improve the business and to maintain a motorcycle which provides additional income for the family.

loans.use: To order additional stock of liquor to sell.

loans.name: Shabana's Group

texts.en:
Shabana is 39 years old, married and has six children. All of the children are enrolled in a local school and getting their education. Her husband has a construction supplies business. He has been operating his business for the past many years and has a good number of loyal clients who trust his quality products & services.  

Shabana supports her husband by operating a beauty salon business. She is a beautician and operates her business from her home. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to buy cosmetics and other beauty products like cream, masks etc to improve his business. She has been doing her business for the past eight years and is very confident that an investment will bring her business to a more profitable position. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her third loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained good credit behavior and never missed any meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Shabana.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics & beauty products for her beauty salon

loans.name: Aingaul's Group

texts.en:
Aingaul is the leader of this group. She is 41 and married to a veterinarian. She and her husband have a daughter and a son, both of whom attend school. Aingaul works as a cleaner at school; she also sells milk products to earn additional money.

The family has been engaged in cattle breeding for five years, starting out with an initial investment of 6,000 KGS. With the profits gained from reselling cattle, Aingaul was able to purchase furniture to improve the family’s living conditions. She plans to use this loan to purchase two more cattle for breeding, fattening and further reselling. In the future, Aingaul wishes to open a grocery store. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Namaskali's Group

texts.en:
Namaskali is the leader of this group. She is 62 years old and is unfortunately a widow. She has raised a daughter and two sons.  Her daughter and older son live separately from their mom, and the second son, 13, is studying at a local school. 

Namaskali works as a cleaner.  Her monthly salary is 2000 soms. In order to earn additional money to meet their daily needs, she also breeds livestock and then resells them at a higher price. 

Namaskali has applied for this loan because she needs additional funds to purchase more livestock for breeding, fattening and further reselling. In the future she hopes to expand her business and with the profits gained she wants to improve her family's living conditions.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
This is Margaret.  She is 34 years old and is a resident of Pasay City, Philippines.  She is single and manages her home while operating a business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.

Margaret operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 PHP-worth of cooking oil, or an egg.  Margaret  earns profit by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and people in the local community. She earns a minimum of 400 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue the operations of her business, Margaret is requesting a loan PHP 17,000 loan. She will be utilizing this loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Margaret dreams of acquiring a house and a lot in the near future. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy inventory for her store

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en: Stephen is 22 years old, married and is blessed with two children.  To earn a living, he runs a quarrying business.  He has been in this business for three years and employs four people to assist him in his tasks.  He also operates a mobile phone money transfer business to supplement his income.  Since he joined Faulu Kenya, Stephen has managed to grow his business.  He has requested a loan for 50,000 Kenyan shillings to rent an  excavator and a water pump.

loans.use: rent an excavator and a water pump

loans.name: Anarbu's Group

texts.en:
Anarbu is the leader of this group. She is 52 years old  and is married to a school teacher. Together with her husband, she has raised six children, three of whom are studying at school. 

Anarbu works as a secretary at a school.  With her husband’s help, she also breeds livestock and then resells them at a higher price in order to contribute additional money to family budget.  In this way, the family earns an additional 3000 soms per month. With the money received from this loan,  Anrabu wants to purchase more livestock for breeding. In the near future, she plans to start building a shed for keeping livestock.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George is 44 years old, married and has two children.  He has been quarrying for four years and employs two people in his business.  He also sells fruits to earn extra income.  

Since he joined Faulu Kenya, George has grown his business and hence improved his standard of living.  He hopes to expand his business in five years and employ more people.  He has requested a loan for 30,000 kenyan shillings to buy a water pump and to hire an excavator.

loans.use: buy a water pump and hire an excavator

loans.name: Almakan's Group

texts.en:
Almakan is the leader of this group. She is 63 years old and is unfortunately a widow. She has raised five children, all of whom are married and live separately from their mom. 

In order to earn money to meet her daily needs, Almakan breeds livestock. She started this activity fifteen years ago with an initial investment of 8000 soms. Reselling livestock after fattening them, she earns 2500 soms per month.  With the money received from this loan, Almakan wants to purchase more livestock animals for breeding. In the future, she dreams of building a big house for her children.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Peterson

texts.en:
Peterson is 33 years old, married and has three children.  To earn a living for his family, he operates a barber shop.  He has managed to retain his business for fifteen years because of the financial support from Faulu Kenya.  He has also learned how to manage his business through the training conducted by Faulu Kenya.

Peterson hopes to own a big barber shop in the future.  He has requested a loan for 40,000 Kenyan shillings to buy a shaving machine.

loans.use: buy a shaving machine

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
This is Teresita.  She is 58 years old and is a resident of Cabrera, Pasay City, Philippines.  She is widow with six children, two are already working while the rest still live at home. She, together with her children, manage their own household while operating a business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Teresita operates a school supplies business. It is where one can buy school supplies like pen, bond paper, cartolina and the like, without going to a bookstore.  She gets the supplies at wholesale prices and sells them by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and people in the local community. She earns a minimum of 400 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help continue the operations of her business, Teresita is requesting a 11,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy additional school supply products to expand her inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Teresita hopes to grow her business in the coming years. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy school supplies to resell

loans.name: Erkinbu's Group

texts.en:
Erkinbu is a member of this group. She is 60 years old and is married to a man who works as a mechanic. Together with her husband, she has raised two daughters and a son.  Her son and the older daughter work in Bishkek, and her younger daughter is studying at a university. 

Six years ago, with an initial investment of 5000 soms, Erkinbu started a business selling foodstuff.   At the moment, she earns about 5000 soms per month. She has applied for this loan because she needs additional funds to purchase more foodstuff. In the future, with the profits gained from the business, she wants to repair her house.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to buy foodstuff to sell

loans.name: Shahida

texts.en:
Shahida is an expert in embroidery work. She crafts beautiful embroidered designs on clothes. Mainly, she works for her neighboring clients and earns income for her family. She is a mother of two children. Both of them are young and studying in a nearby school. 

Her husband is also an embroidery expert. He has been operating his business for the past seven years and it is going well for him. He crafts beautiful embroidery designs on clothes, which helps attract more customers. He is very knowledgeable in his work and keeps himself updated about the latest designs and fashion. 

The wedding season is about to arrive and her husband needs money to buy a quantity of embroidery material in bulk. This will help him fulfill the demands of his customers and increase his profits. Therefore, Shahida has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to help her husband in his business. She is very confident that her husband will use the loan in a positive way and expand his business.

loans.use: To buy embroidery material for her embroidery business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy second-hand clothes to sell

loans.name: Islom

texts.ru:
Ислом более 20 лет занимается услугами ремонт автомобилей. Ему в бизнесе помогал сын, но он уехал в Россию на заработки как строитель. Первую заработки сына Ислом израсходовал на свадьбу дочери. Когда его дети были по 2 и 3 годика, его супруга бросила семью, и с тех пор Ислом и его мать вырастили и воспитали детей сами. Ислом метает устроить сына в какую нибудь учебную заведению, что как и другие дети он тоже получил соответствующие образование. Ислом запрашивает займ для покупки оборудование для более качественно ремонтировать автомашины. Ислом надеется, что кредиторы будут поддерживать его и заранее хочет благодарить вас всех за поддержку.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj
texts.en: Islom has more than twenty years of experience in auto repair. His son helped him with the business, but his son went to Russia to work as a builder. The first time his son sent money home, the money was spent on Islom's daughter's wedding. When his children were two and three years old, his wife abandoned the family, and since then Islom and his mother have brought up the children by themselves. Islom dreams of sending his son to college so that, like other children, he could receive an appropriate education. Islom is asking for a loan to buy equipment so that he may better repair cars. Islom hopes that lenders will support him and wants to thank you in advance for your support.

loans.use: to buy equipment so that he may better repair cars

loans.name: Aslon

texts.ru: Аслон проживает в районе Яван. Ему 70 лет. Он женат. У него семеро детей. Двое его сыновей находятся на заработках заграницей. Сам Аслон имеет высшее педагогическое образование. По профессии он проработал 27 лет. На сегодняшний день Аслон занимается растениеводством. Он арендует участок земли, где выращивает овощи для продажи. Этим видом деятельности он занимается уже девять лет. Кредит берет для посева бахчевых культур. То есть для закупа семян и минеральных удобрений.
texts.en: Aslon lives in Yavan. He is 70 years old, married, and has seven children. His two sons are earning money abroad. Aslon has a higher education in pedagogy.  He worked in his profession for 27 years. Now, Aslon farms. He rents the land where he grows vegetables. He has been doing this work for nine years. He is taking out a loan to plant melons, primarily to buy seeds and fertilizers.

loans.use: to plant melons

loans.name: Altynbu's Group

texts.en:
Altynbu is the treasurer of this group. She is 42 and works as a social worker in the Regional Social Funds. She is married to a builder who went to work in Russia. Altynbu takes care of her son, who is 12 and studies at school. In order to earn additional money to meet their needs, Altynbu breeds livestock. She started this activity four years ago with an initial investment of 13,000 soms. At the moment, reselling livestock after being fattened, she earns an additional 1,500 soms per month. With money received from the loan, Altynbu wants to purchase more livestock for breeding. In the near future, she plans to expand a shed for keeping livestock.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Asuncion

texts.en:
This is Asuncion, 51. She is a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. Asuncion is a single parent with two children; the eldest is already in college, while the youngest is in high school. Together with her children, she manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Asuncion operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a 5-pesos worth of cooking oil or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 450 Philippine Pesos (Php) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php37,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Asuncion hopes her business grows into a mini-grocery and dreams to be able to give her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Viviana

texts.en:
Viviana works hard to support her family.  She is single and has a business selling shrimp paste in the Philippines.  Viviana has been in this business for 20 years.

She requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more ingredients of shrimp paste.

In the future, Viviana would like to save money so that she can expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more ingredients of shrimp paste

loans.name: Veronicah

texts.en: Veronicah is 28 years old and a single-mother of an eight-year-old child.  She has been operating a grocery shop to earn a living.  Her business is five years old and she has employed one person. She is also employed. Since she joined Faulu Kenya, she has been economically empowered. Veronicah hopes to improve her business and become financially stable in the future. She needs 30,000 Kenya shillings to buy fruits and vegetables.

loans.use: To buy fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Salve

texts.en:
Salve is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a business of buying and selling firewood in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 17,000 through NWTF to purchase more stocks to sell for her business.

Salve has been in this business for 8 years however she earns more income from raising pigs.

Salve has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF.  She dreams to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks to sell

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida is 49 years old and married with five children.

She works hard to provide for her family.  Zenaida runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more products to sell.

Zenaida has borrowed and paid 17 loans from NWTF before this loan.  She has been running the general store for 4 years and also earns an income from food vending.

Zenaida aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more products to sell

loans.name: Safia's Group

texts.en:
Safia is 58 years old, married and has four children: two sons and two daughters. Her eldest daughter is a seamstress while others are studying. Safia also sews clothes for her neighboring customers to earn profits. She is very good at her work and receives regular orders every month. Her husband works in a hospital and has a low income.
 
Safia has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her clothes sewing business. With the loan, she will buy cloth, thread and laces to sew beautiful dresses for her customers and earn better profits. She has been operating her business for the past four years and is very confident that an investment will help her to increase her profits by providing better quality work to her customers. 

Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Safia.

loans.use: To buy cloth, thread and laces for her sewing business

loans.name: Elena's Group

texts.en:
Elena is the leader of this group. She is 39 and married to a builder. Four years ago with an initial investment of 500 soms, Elena started to breed poultry and pigs. At the moment, her monthly profit is 2,000 soms. She applied for the loan because she needs additional financial funds for purchasing more chickens and pigs. She hopes that the loan will help her to improve the business. In the future with the profits gained, she plans to repair the house.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase chickens and pigs to breed

loans.name: Roselyn

texts.en:
Roselyn is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a natural medicines business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing 15,000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) through NWTF to purchase medicines, powdered milk, etc. to sell. 

Roselyn has been in this business for four years. Roselyn earns additional income from fish vending and hog raising. 

Roselyn has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of loans from NWTF. She dreams of building and expanding her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase medicines, powdered milk etc. to sell

loans.name: Mariza

texts.pt:
Nasceu em Manhiça, provincia de Maputo, sul de Moçambique, viuva e mãe de 3 filhos dos quais dois frequentam a escola, e o outro ainda não tem idade escolar. Fez a 7ª classe e parou por falta de condições financeiras. Vive na casa propria com a sua familia e sustenta a sua enteada que vive com ela. 

Saiu da sua terra natal quando contraiu matrimonio, é pensionista e negociante ha mais de 12 anos onde dedica-se a compra e venda de produtos diversos, e tem um rendimento de cerca de 3.750.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e poupa algum na sua conta bancaria (BIM).
Nunca fez emprestimo noutros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku atravez de uma amiga que tambem é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu segundo emprestimo na Hluvuku no valor de 10.000.00mt, com qual pretende comprar material de construção DE CASA( cimento, areia, pedra, barrotes, e outros.) para dar continuidade a sua obra. Oprimeiro emprestimo foi de: 10.000.00mt, para o inicio da obra.
Pretende concluir a sua casa para melhor confortar a sua familia e apostar na educação dos filhos, assim irá solicitar mais emprestimos a Hluvuku.
texts.en:
Mariza was born in Manhiça in the southern Mozambique province of Maputo. She is a widow and mother of 3 children, two of whom go to school while the third is past school age. She made it through the 7th grade, but dropped out due to financial hardship. She lives in her own house with her family and also looks after her stepdaughter, who lives with her. 

She left her hometown when she got married and she has been a pensioner and a business woman for over 12 years. She buys and sells a variety of products, earning her a monthly income of 3,750 Mozambique Meticais (MZN), which she puts toward her household expenses and some of which she saves in her personal bank account (BIM). She has never taken out a loan from another bank. 

She came to know Hluvuku [Kiva field partner] through a friend who is also a Hluvuku client. This 10,000 MZN loan will be her second with Hluvuku and she intends to use it to buy construction materials for her home (cement, sand, stones, beams, etc.) in order to continue her home improvement work. Her first loan was 10,000 MZN to begin the construction work. She plans to finish her house to improve the living conditions of her family and to support her children's education. Thus, she intends to take out further loans with Hluvuku.

loans.use: to buy construction materials for her home (cement, sand, stones, beams, etc.)

loans.name: Bunafsha

texts.ru: Бунафша проживает в районе Яван. Ей 44 года. Он замужем. Ее муж находится на заработках в России. Бунафша имеет четверых детей. У нее среднее образование. Она зарабатывает путем разведения мелко - рогатого скота. В этой области она уже шесть тел. Кредит берет для закупа овец.
texts.en: Bunafsha lives in Yavan. She is 44 years old and married. Her husband works in Russia. Bunafsha has four children. She has a secondary education. She earns a living by breeding sheep and goats.  She has a flock of six.  She is taking out a loan to buy sheep.

loans.use: to buy sheep

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fishing business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing 10,000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) through NWTF to purchase fishing gear and bamboo for her fishing business. 

Imelda has been in this business for seven years. She earns additional income from a variety store. 

Imelda has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase fishing gear and bamboo

loans.name: Robert

texts.en: Robert is 29 years old and single. He uses his bicycle to supply cakes to retail shops.  He joined Faulu Kenya so that he would access financial resources easily. Through Faulu Kenya, he has also learned how to manage his finances by saving his money. Robert hopes to open a bakery in the future and become the major supplier of cakes in his local community.  He has requested 20,000 Kenya shillings to buy cakes.

loans.use: To buy cakes to sell

loans.name: Ecitane

texts.pt:
Nasceu  na cidade  de Maputo, provincia  do  mesmo  nome, sul  de Moçambique, solteira e mãe de 5 filhos  dos  quais  todos  frequentam  a  escola. Fez  a  6ª classe  e  parou  por  falta  de condições financeiras. Vive na casa propria com a sua familia e não sustenta mais ninguem. 

Nunca saiu da sua terra natal, é empregada domestica ha mais de 2 anos e tem um salario de  3.000.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e poupa algum na sua conta bancaria (BIM).
Já fez emprestimo na PROCREDIT no valor de 5.000.00mt destinado ao inicio da sua obra, o qual conseguiu pagar sem dificuldades. Conheceu a Hluvuku atravez de uma amiga que tambem é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu primeiro emprestimo na Hluvuku no valor de 10.000.00mt, com qual pretende comprar material DE CONSTRUCAO DE UMA CASA ( ferro, cimento, areia, pedra, barrotes, e outros.) para dar continuidade a sua obra.
Pretende concluir a sua casa para melhor confortar a sua familia, assim irá solicitar mais emprestimos a Hluvuku.
texts.en:
Ecitane was born in the city of Maputo, in the province of the same name, in southern Mozambique. She is single and mother of 5 children, all of whom go to school. She made it through the 6th grade, but dropped out due to financial hardship. She lives in her own house with her family and has no other dependents to care for. 

She has never left her homeland and has been a domestic worker for over 2 years, which provides her a monthly income of 3,000 Mozambique Meticais (MZN), which she puts toward her household expenses and some of which she saves in her personal bank account (BIM). 

She has already taken out a 5,000 MZN loan from PROCREDIT to start her construction project, which she has had no trouble in paying off. She came to know Hluvuku [Kiva field partner] through a friend who is also a Hluvuku client. This 10,000 MZN loan is her first with Hluvuku and she intends to use it to buy construction materials for her house (iron, cement, sand, stone, beams, etc) in order to continue her home improvement work. She intends on finishing her house in order to improve the living conditions of her family, and so she plans to request further loans with Hluvuku.

loans.use: to buy construction materials for her house (iron, cement, sand, stone, beams, etc).

loans.name: Laurencina

texts.pt:
Nasceu  na  provincia  de Inhambane, sul  de Moçambique, casada e mãe de 5 filhos  dos  quais  3 frequentam  a  escola e os outros constituiram familia. Fez  a  7ª classe  e  parou  por  falta  de condições financeiras. Vive na casa propria com a sua familia e não sustenta mais ninguem. 

Saiu da sua terra natal quando contraiu matrimonio, é negociante ha mais de 14 anos e dedica-se a compra e venda de produtos diversos, e  tem um rendimento de cerca de 6.000.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e poupa algum na sua conta bancaria (BIM).
Nunca fez emprestimo noutros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku atravez de uma amiga que tambem é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu primeiro emprestimo na Hluvuku no valor de 10.000.00mt, com qual pretende comprar material PARA CONSTRUCAO DE UMA CASA ( pranchas, ferro, cimento, areia, pedra, barrotes, e outros.) para a sua obra.
Pretende concluir a sua casa para melhor confortar a sua familia, assim irá solicitar mais emprestimos a Hluvuku.
texts.en:
Laurencina was born in Inhambane Province in southern Mozambique. She is married and has five children; three of them go to school, and the others have started their families. Laurencina finished seventh grade and quit school because she could not afford it. She lives in her own house with her family and does not support anyone else.

She left her hometown when she got married. For more than 14 years Laurencina has been a businesswoman who buys and sells various products, and she earns about 6,000 meticais per month. She uses the money for household expenses and saves some in her bank account (at BIM).

She has never had loans from other banks, and she learned about Hluvuku through a friend who is also a customer of this institution. This is Laurencina's first Hluvuku loan. She is asking for 10,000 meticais to buy construction materials (planks, iron, cement, sand, stone, beams and other items) for building her house.

She plans to finish the house in order to make her family more comfortable, so she will ask Hluvuku for more loans.

loans.use: to buy home construction materials (planks, iron, cement, sand, stone, beams, etc.).

loans.name: Bilqees' Group

texts.en:
Bilqees is 44 years old, married, and her husband has a business of selling onions. He puts the onions on his cart and visits different streets of the city for selling. Bilqees also works in people's homes. She earns a reasonable income from her efforts. 

She has 6 children. Her eldest daughter sews clothes, while her eldest son also sells onions. 
 
She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her husband’s business. With the loan, he will purchase onions and also add potatoes in bulk quantity because during Ramadan (a holy month during which Muslims keep a fast), the purchasing of onions and potatoes increases compared to other days, and this will allow him to make more sales and increase his profits. 

Bilqees is very confident about the growth of her husband’s business as a result of this investment. He has been operating his business for the past 10 years. 

Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Bilqees.

loans.use: To buy onions and potatoes for selling

loans.name: Bebelita

texts.en:
Bebelita is 50 years old and single. 

Bebelita works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 25,000 Philippine Peso (PHP) loan through NWTF to buy more items to sell in her store. 

Bebelita has borrowed and repaid four loans from NWTF before this one. She has been running the general store for six years and also earns an income from video rentals. 

Bebelita aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell in her store

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
As a married mother of five children, Helen works hard to support her family. 

She has a business that sells purified drinking water in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from selling food and ready-to-wear clothing. Helen is borrowing 25,000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell. 

Helen has been sustaining her business activities through her past five loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Sabagul

texts.ru:
Сабагул целеустремленная и честная женщина. Она замужем и любящая мать 2 детей.  Она занимается купля продажей детской одежды. Более 11 лет она занимается торговлей и у неё очень богатый опыт. Сегодняшний день Сабагул хочет расширить свой бизнес и максимизировать свой прибыль. Она хочет, устроит своих детей в престижную школу, чтобы они выросли образованными и хорошими людьми. Сабагул запрашивает займ в размере 1400$ США для покупки школьную одежду. Она надеется, что кредиторы будут поддерживать её. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj
texts.en: Sabagul is a goal-oriented and honest woman.  She is a married and loving mother of two children.  She is involved in buying and selling of children's clothing.  She has been involved in retail sales for over eleven years and has a rich experience in this field.  Today Sabagul wants to expand her business and maximize her profits.  She wants to place her children into a prestigious school, so that they would grow up to become educated and good people.  Sabagul is requesting a loan in the sum of $1400 for the purchase of school clothing.  She hopes that creditors will support her.

loans.use: to purchase school clothing

loans.name: Maria

texts.pt:
Nasceu  em Magude,  provincia  de Maputo, sul  de Moçambique, viúva  e  mãe  de 7 filhos  dos  quais  1 frequenta  a  escola e os outros constituiram suas familias. Nunca teve oportunidade de estudar  por  falta  de condições financeiras. Vive na casa propria com a sua familia e não sustenta mais ninguem.
