For 11 years he has been running his business in persistent way and has gained much experience in this field. He is a very sensitive businessman and a new  academic year is starting soon, which means there will be a lot of shoes necessary and a lot of purchases from his shoes kiosk. 

He feels that if he can increase his business' current assets, likewise his income is going to increase slowly. Now he needs to buy a large number of shoes from his suppliers.

loans.use: To buy a large number of shoes to increase his sales and current assets.

loans.name: Umazi

texts.en:
Umazi is a married woman with nine children. Seven of her children attend school and two are adults. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past 10 years, she has operated a vegetable stall business, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality. During the summer hot season the availability of vegetables for resale is lower. She dreams of expanding her business in the future. 

With the KSHS 10,000, she wants to purchase sacks of vegetables for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a sewing machine.

loans.name: Batmunkh

texts.en:
Mr. Batmunkh is 46 and lives with his daughter and wife in their own house in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He runs dual businesses; one is a taxi service and one is a host of second hand raw materials sale point. He started his businesses last year and he has been trying to build his businesses. 

Recently his taxi car has become very old and damaged. So he needs to make a repair and change the parts of his car because this business is his main income source. The loan he is taking will be dedicated to purchase new spare parts for his car.

loans.use: To purchase new spare parts for his car.

loans.name: Mariam's Group

texts.en:
Mariam’s group is comprised of five hard working women. Mariam is 21 years old and lives in the town of Zanna in the Kampala west region of Uganda.  She is married and has three children.  All of her children are currently in school.  Mariam has a business selling charcoal, which she has had for less than one year.         

To help expand her business, Mariam has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase charcoal for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Mariam hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children.  In the future, Mariam hopes to expand her business. Mariam is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by improving her business.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Miriam

texts.en:
Miriam is a single mother of three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has piped water but not electricity. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

For the past year she has operated a medical clinic; her potential customers are neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. Miriam dreams of getting a bigger loan to expand her business in the future. 

With the 20,000 Kenyan Shillings (KES) she wants to purchase medicine for the clinic. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase medicine for the clinic.

loans.name: Hadijja's Group

texts.en:
Hadijja’s group is comprised of three hard-working women. Hadijja is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala west region of Uganda. She is married and has two children, both of whom attend school. For the past three years, Hadijja has had a business selling food.         

To help expand her business, Hadijja has requested a loan of 500,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase food for resale. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Hadijja hopes to generate greater profits and buy food for her family. In the future, Hadijja hopes to expand her business. Hadijja is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by improving her business.

loans.use: to purchase food for resale

loans.name: Prossy's Group

texts.en:
Prossy’s group is comprised of two hard working women. Prossy is 17 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala district of Uganda.  She is single and has no children. She is in the business of selling charcoal, which she has been doing for 5 years.  She also sells food as a secondary business.  

To help expand her business, Prossy has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase charcoal for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Prossy hopes to generate greater profits and pay her own school fees.  In the future, she hopes to expand her business.  She is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by improving her business.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Saha

texts.en:
Saha is a married man with three children, all of whom attend school. He owns a house that has piped water but not electricity. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past five years, he has operated a business selling charcoal from his home to his neighbours and passers-by. His major challenge is the high cost of transportation in his business. Saha dreams of expanding his business in the future.

With the 40,000 KES loan, he wants to purchase sacks of charcoal and firewood for resale. He decided to join Yehu to access loans in order to improve his business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of charcoal and firewood for resale.

loans.name: Jowe's Group

texts.en:
Jowe's group is comprised of two hard-working women. Jowe is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala west region of Uganda.  She is single and has three children. Two of her children attend school. Jowe has a business selling charcoal, which she has had for two years.         

To help expand her business, Jowe has requested a loan of 400,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase charcoal for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Jowe hopes to generate greater profits and buy food for her family. In the future, Jowe hopes to own a retail shop.  Jowe is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by improving her business.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Samit

texts.en: 52 year old Samit is a housewife. Her husband is a construction worker with an income of $10 per day. She has three children, all of whom work in the factory for $3 per day each. Every month, she has to spend $60 on food, $9 on electricity, and $20 on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of $1000 to buy eggs for resale. This loan will help her to build a career that can generate income to support the family. In the future, she hopes to have enough money to rebuild her house and make it better than it currently is.

loans.use: To buy eggs for resale

loans.name: Justice Group

texts.fr: La leader du groupe d’affaire « Justice », est entrepreneur, âgée de 32 ans, veuve, mère de 3 enfants qui étudient tous. Dans la photo, elle est la femme positionnée à l’ extrême, elle s’habille en blouse noire, elle lève sa main Elle est  vendeuse des pagnes. Son mari fut décédé d’une mort inopinée. Elle installe ses marchandises au marché central de  Virunga. Il y a 14 ans révolus qu’elle exerce ces petites activités génératrices de revenus de ce genre. Cependant, elle vient de réaliser  6  cycles avec le crédit de Hekima. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir  de s’approvisionner avec  12 pièces de pagnes  à marchander.  En plus, elle ambitionne scolariser ses enfants et  construire une maison à mettre a location.  La cliente remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres femmes veuves exclues de banque classique. Il sied de signaler que le groupe d’affaire « Justice » est majoritairement féminins.
texts.en:
This leader  of the business group  « Justice », is an entrepreneur of 32, a widowed mother of three children who are all enrolled in school. In the photo she is on the far right in the black blouse, with her hand raised. She sells African print cloth. Her husband died an untimely death. She displays her merchandise at the central market of Virunga. She has been in various small income-generating activities of this sort for 14 years. However, she has just completed her sixth loan with Hekima. 

This new loan will serve to purchase 12 lengths of cloth for resale. Moreover she would like to have her children in school and build a house to rent out. The client thanks Hekima for its work to help poor widows who are not served by conventional banks. It is worth noting that the business group  « Justice » is mostly made up of women.

loans.use: to buy 12 lengths of African print cloth.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a motorbike for traveling to work

loans.name: Sarah's Group

texts.en:
Sarah’s group is comprised of three hard working women. Sarah is 19 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala district of Uganda.  She is single and has no children. For the past year she has been running a small retail shop that sells soap and sugar.         

To help expand her business, Sarah has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase essential commodities like sugar and soap for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Sarah hopes to generate greater profits and buy food for her family.  In the future, she hopes to expand her business. She is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by improving her business.

loans.use: to purchase essential commodities like sugar and soap for resale.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is a single mother of one girl who attends school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, electricity, clothing and school fees. 

For the past seven years, she has operated a motor vehicle transport business. She has also operated a video café business which provides her with another source of income. She faces a major challenge of competition in her business. She dreams of expanding her business in the future. With her KES 20,000 loan she wants to purchase spare parts to service her motor vehicle. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts to service her motor vehicle.

loans.name: Mom

texts.en: 38 year old Mom is a housewife. Her husband sells pigs, and earns an income of $10 per day. She has four children; one is studying and the other three are working in the factory, with a combined income of $15. Every month, Mom has to spend $75 on food, $4 on electricity, $10 on school fees, and $10 on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of $700 to buy a motorbike for her husband to transport baby pigs to sell in the village and nearby. In the future, she wants to buy a small car for her husband, so that he can sell more pigs and earn more money. She wants to send her last child to university so that he can get a good job in the future.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her husband to transport baby pigs to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase two bundles of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Chanthouen

texts.en: 27 year old Chanthouen sells vegetables with her husband and makes $5 per day. She has two children, aged 1 and 2 years. Every month, she has to spend $80 on food, $5 on electricity, and $10 on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of $500 to buy pigs to raise and then sell. This loan will help her family to have another income besides selling vegetables, and will enable them to save money for sending her children to school when they are ready.

loans.use: To buy pigs to raise and sell

loans.name: Jean Claude Anastase

texts.fr:
Jean Claude Anastase  est née au Rwanda et a 37 ans. Ile est marie et il a 4 enfants de 2 à 12 ans, dont 3 scolarisés. Son niveau d’éducation est 8 ans de primaire. 
Jean Claude Anastase  est commerçant de téléphone mobile et ses accessoires. C’est son cinquième  cycle de prêt avec ACB. Il va utiliser son crédit pour acheter 13 nouveaux téléphones Nokia, 10 nouveau téléphones Motorola, 25 carte Sim, 40 batteries des téléphones et pour augmenter son business.  
Son stratégie pour la croissance de son business est vendre des matériels de qualité pour attire la marché et avoir beaucoup des matériels pour son business. Dans les prochaines années, Jean Claude Anastase  voudrait se développer son projet et devenir un grand homme d’affaire. Avec les profits, il prévoit de payer les frais scolaires de ses enfants et bâtir sa propre maison commerciale.
texts.en:
Jean Claude Anastase  was born in Rwanda and is 37. He is married and has four children between 2 and 12, of whom three are in school. He got through eight years of primary school. 
 
Jean Claude Anastase  sells cell phones and accessories. This is his fifth loan with ACB. He is going to use his loan to buy 13 new Nokia phones, 10 new Motorola phones, 25 Sim rechargeable phone cards, and 40 telephone batteries and grow his business. 

His strategy for growing his business is to sell top-quality materials to attract clients and have a lot of inventory available. In the coming years, Jean Claude Anastase  would like to develop his business and become a big businessman. With his profit, he plans to pay school fees for his children and build his own store.

loans.use: to buy 13 new Nokia phones, 10 new Motorola phones, 25 Sim rechargeable phone cards, and 40 telephone batteries and grow his business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase plates, pots and frying pans.

loans.name: Bashiraan's Group

texts.en:
Bashiraan is 52 years old, married and has two sons. Her husband has a carpet weaving business. He is very skillful and weaves beautifully-designed carpets, which sell for a very good price. Bashiraan couldn’t educate her sons due to financial constraints. They are involved with their father in his business of weaving and selling carpets. 
 
Bashiraan has a clothes-selling business. She purchases them from a wholesale market and sells to her local area clients at a profit. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy thread and tools, which will enable him to weave better quality carpets and earn extra income. He is very experienced in his business and has been operating it for past 10 years. Bashiraan hopes that an investment will help him improve his business and income.

Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Bashiraan.

loans.use: To buy thread and tools for carpet weaving

loans.name: Millah

texts.en:
Millah is a single woman with three children (two boys and one girl). She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, clothing and school fees. 

For the past year, Millah has operated a food stall, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of competition from other food stall operators in the area. She dreams of establishing another business in the future. With her KES 40,000 loan she wants to purchase sacks of Irish potatoes, rice and beans. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of Irish potatoes, rice and beans.

loans.name: Sophal

texts.en: 42 year old Sophal is a farmer. Together with his wife he earns $7 per day. He has five children, all of whom are farmers who help to plow the farm to make money. Every month, he has to spend $80 on food, $20 on rent, and $25 on other expenses. He would like to request a loan of $1000 to buy groceries for his daughter to sell at home. This loan will help his daughter to have a career, to support herself, and to be able to make a better income then she can from farming. In the future, he wants to help his sons to study a skill that can help them to get a better job.

loans.use: To buy groceries for his daughter to sell at home

loans.name: Bokk Jom Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité Bokk Jom est créé depuis le 28 juin 2010, il est composé de quinze femmes qui sont voisines et s'entendent bien; elles s'activent dans le commerce.


La responsable Anta est âgée de 44 ans,elle est mariée mère de six enfants; elle mène une activité de vente de légumes depuis environ 15 ans, elle a une bonne expérience. Elle est debout tout à fait à droite sur la photo  habillée en boubou saumon avec un châle blanc sur l'épaule et a levé la main gauche.


Elle s'approvisionne dans les villages maraîchers et revend au marché central de la ville.

Son prêt lui servira à renforcer son activité afin de se faire plus de revenus.

Elle aide son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes avec ses bénéfices obtenus; mais investi aussi dans les tontines une façon d'épargner pour préparer son remboursement.
texts.en:
The solidarity group Bokk Jom was formed on June 28, 2010. It is made up of 15 women who are neighbors and get along well; they are active in commerce. 

The leader of the group, Anta, is 44 years old. She is a married mother of six children. She has been in the business of selling vegetables for about 15 years. She has good experience. She is standing all the way to the right of the photo dressed in a salmon-colored dress with a white shawl on her shoulder and her left hand raised. 

She stocks up in the village markets and resells in the central market of the city. 

The loan will serve to strengthen her business in order to make more income. 

She helps her husband with the daily expenses with the income received but also invested in tontines as a way to save to prepare for her repayment.

loans.use: To buy vegetables intended for sale

loans.name: Saveit

texts.en: Saveit, 56 years old, sells fruit with her husband. Their income is 5 USD per day. She has three children, all of whom work. The combined income for everyone in her family is 9 USD. She also has three grandchildren, so there are a total of eight family members. Every month, she spends 70 USD on food, 15 USD on electricity, 19 USD on rent, 30 USD on transportation, and 10 USD on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of 600 USD to buy a motorbike for transporting the fruit that she sells. In the future, she wants to sell more kinds of fruit so that she can earn more income. She wants to support her grandchildren's education through high school.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for transporting fruit

loans.name: Sarom

texts.en: Sarom, 32 years old, makes offering goods to sell with her husband. She can earn $10 per day for her income. She has four children and all of them are studying. Every month, she has to spend $50 on food, $7 on electricity, $15 on rent, $30 on school fees, $14 on transportation and $10 on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of $900 to buy materials to make more offerings to sell. She has a lot of customers ordering offerings from her to resell, so she needs to make more offering goods for them. Her career can make a good income for her family, especially because all of her family can be involved in doing it together.

loans.use: To buy material for making offerings to sell

loans.name: Everlyne

texts.en:
Everlyne is a widowed woman with two boys who have already graduated from school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, clothing, electricity and school fees for her two granddaughters. 

For the past 20 years, she has operated a water vending business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. In addition, she also operates a food stall and a play station, which contributes to her other source of income. She faces a major challenge of competition from other water vendors in the area. Everlyne dreams of establishing real estate houses in the future.

With the KSHS 80,000, she wants to purchase a motorcycle to start a transport business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle to start a transport business.

loans.name: Vath

texts.en: Vath, 50 years old, is a housewife. Her husband is a security guard at school with $2 per day for his income. She has three children. One of her children is studying and the other two are working for $6 per day for all. Every month she has to spend $50 in food, $5 on electricity, $5 on school fees, and $10 on other expenses.  She would like to request a loan of $1,200 to buy a motorbike for her son who is providing a motorcycle transport service. In the future, she hope to buy another motorbike for another of her sons to provide motorcycle taxi service as well because this career can make a good income in her province. She wants to support her last child to study until he finishes at the university.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her son to provide motorcycle taxi service

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah lives in the Nakulabye neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is single and has three children. Two of her children are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members (two of her brother's children). Sarah has a business of fruits and vegetables. She has been in this business for three years and she works seven days out of every week. Sarah sells her products at the market at wholesale. Sarah has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more boxes of tomatoes and onions. She also generates additional income by renting houses. The main business challenge(s) for Sarah include transportation and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a delivery van and to start growing tomatoes. Sarah lives in a home that she owns. She has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of tomatoes and onions

loans.name: Nang

texts.en: Nang, 45 years old, sells cakes and food. Her husband is a farmer and their income is $9 per day. They live with one child and one grandson. Every month she has to spend $50 on food, $30 on transportation and $10 on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of $700 to buy goods and materials for making more food and cakes to sell. In the future, she hopes to have enough money to repair her house to be better than it is now.

loans.use: To buy goods and materials to make food and cakes to sell

loans.name: Boniface

texts.en:
Boniface is a married man who lives in a rental house that has electricity, but not piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food, rent, and electricity.

For the past five years, he has operated a bread selling business, selling door-to-door to retailers. He faces the major challenge of competition, and high transportation costs in his business. Boniface dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future. 

With the KES 40,000, he wants to purchase a bicycle to be used in bread distribution for the business. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: To purchase a bicycle to be used in bread distribution for the business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy motorbike parts for repairing the motorbikes of customers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Lamula

texts.en: Lamula  lives in Uganda. She is single, and has three children all of whom are in school.  Lamula has a business of selling second-hand clothes. She has been in this business for three years, and she works seven days out of every week. Lamula sells her products at the market by means of retail. Lamula has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bales of second-hand clothes. The main business challenge(s) for Lamula include transportation and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start importing clothes, and also to become a wholesale business. Lamula lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second-hand clothes.

loans.name: Waly

texts.fr: Monsieur Waly  vit au Sénégal. Il est marié et gère  un robinet public de distribution d’eau  dans son quartier d’habitation.  Parallèlement  il dispose d’un champ au village et s’adonne a l’agriculture. Il a choisi ces deux occupations dans le but d’avoir une source de revenus et de faire face aux difficultés de la vie quotidienne. Ce qui l’intéresse le plus dans son activité c’est la satisfaction de la clientèle. Il est sociétaire de l’un des guichets de l’U-IMCEC depuis juin 2010. Il sollicite un crédit de 100 000 frs qui servira à l’achat de semences en cette période d’hivernage. Son vœu est d’exploiter son   champ qui se trouve au village. Ce financement lui permettra d’améliorer ses revenus, de subvenir a ses besoins et gérer sa famille.
texts.en:
Monsieur Waly  lives in Sénégal. He is married and manages a public faucet for water distribution in his neighborhood. At the same time, he has a field in the village and works at agricultural pursuits. He has chosen these two occupations to have a source of income to keep pace with the difficulties of daily life. What interests him most in his business is satisfying his clientele. 

He has been a member of one of the branches of U-IMCEC since June 2010. He is requesting a loan of 100,000 francs which will allow him to buy seeds to sow during this rainy season. His wish is to take advantage of his field in the village. This loan will allow him to increase his income, support himself, and manage his family.

loans.use: to buy seeds to sow.

loans.name: Sun

texts.en: Sun is 63 years old, and is a farmer with $1.5 per day for her income. She is single mother with two children. They are all working with $6 per day for all. Every month, she has to spend $47 on food, $3 on electricity, and $10 on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of $1000 to buy a cow for  selling livestock. She hopes to have more money to buy more cows for livestock sales so that she can make more income to repair her house.

loans.use: To buy a cow for selling livestock.

loans.name: Khalida's Group

texts.en:
Khalida is 45 years old and has two sons. Her eldest son supports his father financially by operating a barber shop and the youngest one stays at home. He is 17 years old and doesn’t do anything. Khalida’s husband makes food on order for different parties. His taste in hands enables him to increase his client base and earn good profits every month.
  
Khalida is a very supportive lady by nature. She supports her husband in managing the household expenses by sewing clothes for her neighborhood clients. She is very good in her profession and receives regular orders every month. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy the required ingredients & utensils (big cooking pots) to make food of good quality and in larger quantity to fulfill his orders and earn a good income. He has been operating his business for the past 10 years and Khalida is very confident about the future growth of her husband’s business as a result of the loan. 
 
Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Khalida.

loans.use: To buy ingredients & utensils to make food to sell

loans.name: Run

texts.en: Run is 51 years old, and is a rice seller who earns $4 per day. She is a single mother with one child. He is working in Thailand; his income is $6 per day. Every month, she has to spend $30 on food, $10 on electricity, and another $5 on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of $500 to buy rice for resale. This loan will help her to have enough money to buy rice for selling, and she hopes to have more money to buy a stock of rice to sell when there is a good price.

loans.use: To buy rice for resale.

loans.name: Sum

texts.en: Sum is 50 years old, and is a farmer. Her husband is a carpenter. She has five children, three are studying, one is working in the factory, and one more is selling fruit. Their income is $6 per day for each working member. Every month, she has to spend $90 on food, $5 on electricity, $5 on school fees, and $10 on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of $700 to buy fruit for her daughter to sell. She hopes her daughter’s career will start going well, and that she will be able to make a good income to support the family. She hopes to send the rest of her children to study in the university when they finish high school.

loans.use: To buy fruit for her daughter to sell.

loans.name: Ta

texts.en: Ta is 26 years old, and is a garment factory worker. Her husband is a worker, and their income is $4 per day. She has two children, they are twins and are three years old. Every month, she has to spend $30 on food, $5 on electricity, $5 on transportation, and $20 on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of $650 to buy a motorbike for traveling to work with her husband. She hopes to have enough money to repair her house, and able to send all of her children to study at least through high school.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for traveling to work.

loans.name: Nakree

texts.en: Nakree is 30 years old, and is a farmer. Her husband is a motor taxi driver, their income is $5 per day. She has one child; he is four years old. Every month, she has to spend $40 on food, $5 on transportation, and $10 on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of $600 to buy a Tok-Tok for her husband to run a Tok Tok service, so that he can make a better income. She hopes her husband's career can improve so that she can have enough money for repairing her house.

loans.use: To buy a Tok-Tok for her husband to run a Tok-Tok service

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah Nakibuule lives in the Nakulabye neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is single and has two children, both of whom are in school.  Sarah has a business of selling charcoal.  She has been in this business for four years, and she works seven days out of every week.  Sarah sells her products at the market, by means of retail.  Sarah has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal. She also generates additional income through a pay phone. The main business challenge(s) for Sarah include defaulters and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to be a wholesaler, and also to start going to villages for charcoal. Sarah lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees, and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal.

loans.name: C9234 Duterimbere Group

texts.en:
Emmanuel is 20 years old. He is single, and he is also the leader of this group which is called "DUTERIMBERE" in the local language. He is the first person on the left side.  Emmanuel employs two people for help, and he has one year of experience in this business. He works from 8 a.m. until 8 p.m. every day. 

Emmanuel and his group have requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand their businesses. Once their businesses are expanded, they hope to satisfy their customers, and they will be able to reinvest in their businesses, and to save for the future.

loans.use: To increase his business by buying more beans, soap, sugar, rice, and so on to sell.

loans.name: Memunatu

texts.en:
Memunatu is 45 years old and married with three children between 16 and 23 years old. She runs a boutique in the western part of Freetown.

Memunatu has owned this business for 10 years and sells shoes, clothing, shirts and skirts at her boutique. She also earns income from a taxi business. She says that the main challenge to her business is that he construction of the road made her reduce the size of her business.

She requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more clothes, shoes, bags and jewelry. Memunatu says that the extra income from this loan will help her improve her standard of living. In the future, she would like to do international business, importing and exporting of goods.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes, bags, shoes, shirts, and jewelry.

loans.name: Ann

texts.en:
Ann is a married woman with one child who attends school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, rent and school fees.

For the past two years, she has operated a clothes-selling business, selling from door to door to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of competition from other clothes sellers in the area. Ann dreams of establishing a retail shop in the future.

With the KSHS 10,000, she wants to purchase bundles of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema is a single mother of six children: two boys and four girls. She lives at a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, rent bills, electricity and clothing.

For the past 15 years, she has operated a tailoring business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of competition from other tailors in the area. Rehema dreams of expanding her business in the future.

With the 20,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase a sewing machine. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine.

loans.name: Mariamu

texts.en:
Mariamu is a single woman with one child who graduated from school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, clothing and electricity bills.

For the past seven years, she has operated a business selling palm wine, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. In addition, she sells charcoal, which contributes to her other source of income. She faces a major challenge of the high cost of transportation in her business. Mariamu dreams of furnishing her house in the future.

With the KSHS 40,000, she wants to purchase ten sacks of charcoal and pay for transport. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase 10 sacks of charcoal and pay for transport.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is a married woman with seven children, three boys and four girls. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, school fees and clothing.

For the past two years, she has operated a water vending business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of competition from other water vendors in the area. She dreams of purchasing another water tank in the future.

With the KSHS 30,000, she wants to establish a vegetable stall business and purchase bundles of vegetables for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of vegetables to sell to establish a vegetable stall business

loans.name: Kadzo

texts.en:
Kadzo is a married woman with five children, two boys and three girls. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, electricity and school fees.

For the past two years, she has operated a vegetable stall business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of competition from other vegetable stall operators. Kadzo dreams of accessing bigger loans to expand her business in the future.

With the KSHS 20,000, she wants to purchase sacks of tomatoes, onions, potatoes and vegetables for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of tomatoes, onions, potatoes and vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Baktygul's Group

texts.en:
Baktygul is the treasurer of this group. She is 55 and married to a teacher. Together with her husband, she brings up two sons, both of whom work in construction in Bishkek. Baktygul works in the post office. Together with her husband, she also breeds livestock animals. By reselling livestock after fattening, the family earns an additional 5,000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase more livestock for breeding. In the future, with the profits gained from reselling livestock, she wants to purchase a house in Bishkek (the capital of Kyrgyzstan).

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Nathaniel

texts.en:
Nathaniel is a married man with four children: two boys and two girls. He owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food, school fees and clothing.

For the past seven years, he has operated a business selling phone accessories, selling in a shop to his neighbors. He faces a major challenge of competition from other sellers in the market. Nathaniel dreams of establishing his own shop in the future.

With the KSHS 20,000, he wants to purchase phone accessories for resale. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: To purchase phone accessories for resale.

loans.name: Gona

texts.en:
Gona is a married man with three children: one boy and two girls. Two of his children attend school while one is still too young for school. He lives in a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are rent bills, food and school fees.

For the past two years, he has operated a charcoal selling business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. He faces a major challenge of the high cost of transportation in his business. He dreams of owning a retail shop in the future.

With the KSHS 20,000, he wants to purchase six sacks of charcoal for resale. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: To purchase six sacks of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Dorah

texts.en: Dorah lives in Uganda. She is single and has two children, both of whom are in school. Dorah has a business selling used clothes. She has been in this business for 10 years and she works seven days out of every week. Dorah sells her products at the market by means of retail. Dorah has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bales of used clothes (shirts). She also generates additional income through poultry farming. The main business challenge(s) for Dorah include defaulters and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to be a wholesaler and to build rental rooms. Dorah lives in a home that she owns. She has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bales of used clothes (shirts )

loans.name: Saron

texts.en: Saron, 27 years old, sells food. Her husband is a motor taxi driver. Their income is $6 per day. She has two children. They are three and one years old. Every month, she has to spend $60 on food, $6 on electricity, and $10 on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of $1,000 to buy grocery goods to sell in front of her house so that she can do two careers at the same time. Her mother-in-law is helping her. In the future, she wants to have a good shop at her house for selling food and groceries. She will work hard to send her children to study in the university.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods to sell at home

loans.name: Macdonald

texts.en:
Macdonald is a married man with one girl who attends school. He lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food, rent bills, school fees and electricity. 

For the past four years, he has operated a tailoring business, selling in a shop to his neighbors and passersby. Macdonald faces a major challenge of competition from other tailors in the area. He dreams of purchasing another sewing machine in the future.

With the KSHS 20,000, he wants to purchase cloth materials for his tailoring business. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve his business.

loans.use: To purchase cloth materials for his tailoring business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Sopha

texts.en: Sopha, 54 years old, is a housewife. Her husband is a motor taxi driver. Their income is $5 per day. She has three children, all of whom are working with $3 per day for each. Every month she has to spend $80 on food, $10 on electricity, $20 on transportation, and $20 on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of $500 to buy a plot of land for doing farming. In the future, she wants to get a small tailoring shop for her daughter to do at home because she can earn a better income than working in the factory.

loans.use: To buy a plot of land for doing farming

loans.name: Parveen's Group

texts.en:
Parveen is 53 years old and married. Her husband has a business selling clothes. He purchases clothes from the wholesale market and sells to his customers at reasonable rates through his shop, which is located in a nearby market. Parveen also supports her husband by selling clothes to her community clients. The income she earns helps her to pay utility bills and other household expenses. She doesn’t have any children so she spends her day operating her business and doing her household tasks. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her husband’s clothes-selling business. With the loan, he will buy a variety of clothes in bulk to put in his shop for selling to his customers. He is very experienced in his work and has been operating it for many years. Parveen is hopeful that an investment will bring even more profits to him. 

Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Parveen.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Sothea

texts.en: Sothea, 52 year old, is a primary teacher. Her husband is a farmer and their income is $6 per day. She has four children. Two of her children are studying and one is working in the factory for $3 per day. Every month, she has to spend $50 on food, $10 on electricity, $50 on school fees, $15 on transportation, and $10 on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of $1,000 to pay for her children's school fees for the university. In the future, she hopes to be able to send all of her children to study in the university.

loans.use: To pay for her children's university fees

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth has practiced farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last 11 years.  She is 50 years old and married to David.

She was introduced to KADET Ltd. by one of our field officers and this will be her fifth loan.  She repaid all her previous loans well and in good time.  She plans to diversify her sources of income, so she will use the loan amount to buy clothes to sell and open up a boutique in Ndunyu Njeru town.

In future, Elizabeth hopes to become one of the leading farmers in Ndunyu Njeru and also open more branches of her boutique.

loans.use: to open a boutique

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence lives in Uganda.  She is single and has 4 children, all of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members (her in-laws).  

Florence has a business selling bananas.  She has been in this business for 5 years and she works 6 days out of every week. Florence sells her products at the market by means of retail. Florence has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bunches of bananas. She also generates additional income through tailoring.

The main business challenges for Florence include transportation and seasonality.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to be a wholesaler and also to own a delivery van. Florence lives in a home that she rents.  She has access to electricity and has access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: to buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Jamil

texts.en:
Jamil is a 29-year-old single Lebanese man living with his parents and one sibling. After graduating from the university, he opened his own pharmacy in 2010. He was eager to start his own business after noticing that there was a real need for such services in the region. He really enjoys his work, especially that he is able to help people improve their heath. 

Today, he is asking to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase additional medicines and beauty treatment products. In the future, he is planning to further expand his business.

loans.use: to purchase additional medicines and beauty treatment products

loans.name: Sokmorn

texts.en:
Sokmorn, 27 years old, is a farmer. Her husband is a construction worker and their income is $8 per day. She has one child and he is two years old. Every month she has to spend $70 on food, $5 on electricity, and $20 on other expenses.

She would like to request a loan of $500 to buy a motorbike for her husband's motor taxi service. In the future, she hopes to have enough money to repair her house to be better than now, and to be able to send all of her children to study or at least finish high school.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for her husband's motor taxi service

loans.name: Melrose

texts.en:
Melrose is 34 years old and married with 4 children aged between 5 and 14. She runs a general merchandise store in the Krootown central part of Freetown.

Melrose has owned this business for 4 years and sells food containers, milk, sugar and umbrellas at her store. She also earns income from small-scale timber construction. She says that the main challenge to her business is the problem of transportation. 

She requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more food containers, suitcases and tinned milks. Melrose says that the extra income from this loan will help her improve her standard of living. In the future, she would like to import goods from overseas and expand her business more.

loans.use: to purchase more food containers, suitcases, tinned milk and umbrellas

loans.name: Josphat

texts.en:
Josphat has practiced farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last eight years.  He is 37 years old, married to Lucy and they have two school-going children.  

He was introduced to KADET Ltd. by one of our field officers and this will be his second loan.  He paid his previous loan of 40,000 KES well and in good time.  He plans to use the loan amount to buy two bulls and four sheep which he will rear and sell later.

In future, Josphat hopes to become one of the leading farmers in the Ndunyu Njeru area.

loans.use: to buy two bulls and four sheep

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 33-year-old married Lebanese man living with his wife and two school-aged children. He has 12 years of experience working as a car painter.  

In 2003, Ali was able to open his own car repair shop. His business went well during the past years and he was even able to hire three full-time employees. But he was also affected badly by unpleasant conditions. And today, he is asking to borrow $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to buy an electric generator needed for his work. He states that this purchase will positively impact his business growth.

loans.use: to buy an electric generator needed for his work

loans.name: Gege

texts.en:
Gege, a married father of three boys and a girl, all of whom attend school, owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For over 10 years, Gege has operated a natural medicine business, selling from home to his neighbours. He faces the major business challenge of competition, and dreams of expanding in the future.

Having joined Yehu to access business loans, Gege wants to start a poultry enterprise with a loan of Kshs 15,000 to purchase chicks and chicken feed.

loans.use: to start a poultry business by purchasing chicks and chicken feed.

loans.name: Hasan

texts.en:
Hasan is a 46-year-old married Lebanese man living with his wife and one child. He has owned a fishery for the past eight years where he sells fish in large quantities. His is the only income source for the family. 

With his requested loan of $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l., he will be able to purchase a fridge in order to keep his products fresh. He has a good business reputation and he is known by his great products' cleanliness. In the future, he is planning to expand his business operation into other areas.

loans.use: to purchase a fridge in order to keep his products fresh

loans.name: Noe

texts.en:
A single mother of four children, all of whom are in school, Noe lives in Uganda in a rented home that has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

For the past 10 years, Noe has had an enterprise selling charcoal from home. She has requested a loan of 300000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO to buy more bags of charcoal. Noe's main business challenges are transportation and seasonality, and her goals are to become a wholesaler and to own a delivery van.

loans.use: to buy more bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Kiova

texts.en:
Kiova is a 27-year-old married woman from Lebanon living with her husband. In order to help with the family expenses, she decided to start working as a private teacher. 

She has been involved in this occupation since 2008, and she gives lessons at student's houses. Today, she is asking to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to perform the needed maintenance on her car so that she can make her transportation easier and safer. In the future, she is planning to get a job in a proper school and make her work a stable source of income.

loans.use: to repair her car so that she can make her transportation easier and safer

loans.name: Mujeres Emprendedoras De Azucena Group

texts.es:
Este Comité se formó a través D. las Señoras Catalina y Noelia, quienes se habían acercado hasta la Oficina D. la Fundación Paraguaya para interiorizarse más del Programa D. Comité D. Mujeres Emprendedoras, la misma invitó a sus amigas y compañeras del Barrio y decidieron sumarse al trabajo grupal para salir adelante y así mejorar su estilo D. vida. Actualmente son 20 mujeres, todas trabajadoras y humildes que deben ganarse el sustento todos los días.
La señora Catalina se dedica a la venta D. leche, comenta que hace tiempo se dedica a esto, por lo que ya tiene muchos clientes bien formados. Dice que todos los días se levanta a muy tempranas horas D. la mañana para que su producto ya esté en la casa D. sus clientes ni bien entrada a la mañana. Uno D. sus sueños es tener un local donD. pueda vender sus lácteos, como así también los derivados del mismo.
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra D. leche, para que D. esa forma pueda abastecerse y cumplir mejor con los pedidos D. sus clientes. Está muy agradecida con la Fundación por la oportunidad que esta le da.
texts.en:
This committee was formed by Señoras Catalina and Noelia, who had approached the office of Fundación Paraguaya to learn more about the Program for the Committee of Women Entrepreneurs.  They invited their friends and colleagues from the neighborhood and decided to join together to work as a group to move ahead in life, and in this way improve their standard of living.  They are currently twenty women, all of whom are hard-working and humble, and who have to earn themselves a living on a daily basis.

Señora Catalina works selling milk.  She comments that she has been doing this for some time, which is why she has a good customer base.  She says that every day she gets up at a very early hour of the morning so that her product is already in her customers' houses well before the morning is underway.  

One of her dreams is to have premises where she can sell her dairy products, and also the things maD. from them. 

She is requesting the loan for the purchase of milk, as in this way she can stock up and better meet the orders of her customers.

She is very grateful to the Fundación for the opportunity it is giving her.

loans.use: to buy milk for subsequent sale.

loans.name: Moufid

texts.en:
Moufid is a 56-year-old married man living with his wife and five children. Two of his children are still attending school. He is from Lebanon. He has 21 years of experience working in the agricultural field. 

In 1995, he bought a small piece of land where he started to cultivate lemons and bananas. Because he is older, he gets help from two part-time workers to complete the farm's hard work. 

Today, he is asking to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to make much-needed repairs on the water canal and purchase fertilizer and seed. He is willing to increase his business productivity, therefore his sales, and thus his income. This will be his second Kiva loan.

loans.use: to make much-needed repairs on the water canal and purchase fertilizer and seed

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to start animal farming.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah  lives in  Uganda.  She is single and has 2 children, all of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members (mother).
   
Sarah has a business selling charcoal.  She has been in this business for 5 years and she works 6 days out of every week.  Sarah sells her products from home, by means of retail.  Sarah has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal.     

She also generates additional income through selling piped water.  The main business challenges for Sarah include increased prices of charcoal and seasonality.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to be a wholesaler and to build and own her own house.  Sarah lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and has access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James has operated in the transport industry in Naivasha town for the last two years.  He is 58 years old, married to Agnes and they have three children. 

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his first loan.  He plans to use the loan amount to buy a new motorcycle. 

In the future, James hopes to buy a pickup truck which he will use to transport goods to and from the market

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike

loans.name: Wissam

texts.en:
Wissam is a 33-year-old married Lebanese man living with his wife and only child. He has been working in the construction field from more than 18 years and he specializes in completing wall foliage work. He began his career at a very young age. Later on, he started to take on his own projects. 

Working on a freelance basis, he managed houses in his village and its surroundings. With the requested loan of $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l., he will purchase added tools and supplies since he intends to grow his business by sticking with projects for bigger houses.

loans.use: to purchase tools and supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more clothes for sale.

loans.name: Marie

texts.en:
Marie is 40 years old and married with 2 children, ages 4 and 22.  She runs a Pharmacy store in Aberdeen-western part in Freetown.  She has 1 employee working with her.  

Marie has been in this business for 5 years and sells malaria drugs, blood tonic and cosmetics at her store.  She also earns income from renting out a house.  She says that the main challenge to her business is problems with transportation to travel with drugs from a neighboring country.

She requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more malaria drugs, blood tonic and cosmetics.  Marie says that the extra income from this loan will help her improve her family status and increase her business level.  In the future, she would like to expand her business to a clinic level.

loans.use: To purchase more malaria drugs, blood  tonic and cosmetics.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to renew his business tools

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John has operated in the transport industry in Naivasha town for the last six years.  He is 27 years old and married to Jane.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his 3rd loan.  He paid off all of his previous loans well and in good time.  He plans to use this loan amount to open up a salon which will be run by his wife.  This will increase their income. 

In the future, John hopes to grow in the transport industry and own a number of minibuses.

loans.use: To open up a salon

loans.name: Afuwa

texts.en:
Afuwa, who lives in Kampala, Uganda, is a married mother of five children, four of whom go to school. She lives in her own house, and her family has access to piped water and electricity. Her monthly expense includes food and power charges.

The operator of a hardware shop for the past five years, Afuwa works seven days a week and is now requesting a loan of 200000 from MCDT SACCO to buy more bags of cement. Her business challenges are insufficient capital and seasonality, and her goals are to expand into a wholesale operation and build her own shop .

loans.use: to buy more bags of cement.

loans.name: Resty

texts.en:
Resty, who lives in Kampala, Uganda, is a married mother of six children, five of whom go to school. She lives in her own house, and the family has access to piped water and electricity. Her monthly expense includes school fees.

For the last 10 years, Resty has been selling tomatoes and matooke (plantains) seven days a week in a shop. Her other source of income is the selling of piped water from home.

Resty has requested a loan of 200000 from MCDT SACCO to buy more bananas and boxes of tomatoes. Her business challenges includes the rainy season and defaulters, and her goals are to educate her children to university level and expand her business into a wholesale operation.

loans.use: to buy more bananas and boxes of tomatoes to sell.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is 52 years old and is married to Rajab. They currently live with their two grandchildren.

Beatrice sells groceries and has applied for her first loan from KADET Ltd. after being introduced by a friend who is also a registered client with KADET Ltd. The profits made from the business will be used to cater to the family's needs.

She hopes to diversify into a clothing business.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to add to her stock.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has four children. Three of them go to school. She also takes care of her sister. She lives in her own house and the family has access to piped water and electricity. Her biggest monthly expense is school fees.

She sells charcoal on a retail basis. She has been in business for the last year. She works seven days a week. Her other source of income is rental houses and Mobile Disco.

She has requested a loan of 200,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO to buy more bags of charcoal. Rose's business challenges include rainy season, which makes roads impassable, and thieves. Her aspiration is to educate her children up to university level.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 45 years old and lives in Musunda in Kakamega town. She is married to Richard and they have two children.

ELizabeth has a retail shop that she has been running for the past six years, and she has applied for her first loan from KADET Ltd. to enable her to buy more stock.

She hopes to see her business expand and be a supermarket.

loans.use: To add stock to her business.

loans.name: Zam

texts.en:
Zam lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has 10 children and five go to school. She has no additional family members. She lives in her own house and her family has access to piped water and electricity. Her monthly expenses include school fees.

She sells sodas and juice. She sells her products on a retail basis in a rented shop. She has been in business for the last six years. She works six days a week. Her other source of income is a restaurant. 

Zam’s business challenges include high rental charges and high costs of soda and passion fruit. She has requested for a loan of 200,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO to buy more crates of sodas. 

Her aspiration is to expand into a wholesale business.

loans.use: To buy more crates of soda.

loans.name: Kuña Guapa Group

texts.es:
El comité KUÑA GUAPA tiene 5 ciclos de formación y trabajo con la Fundación Paraguaya. Las integrantes se sacrifican y luchan día a día para brindar un futuro mejor y distinto a la realidad que a ellas tocó vivir. Actualmente cuenta con 15 miembros, donde todas ellas trabajan dentro de un ambiente de respeto, solidaridad y sobre todo responsabilidad.
La señora Hermelinda tiene una despensa, comenta que tiene muchos clientes que son de su barrio y de zonas aledañas, tiene mucha demanda de todo tipo de productos. Comenta que le gustaría ampliar su local para poder seguir creciendo y de esa forma también ofrecer mayor comodidad a sus clientes. Dice que todo lo que hace es por el bien de su familia y por aquellos que de ella dependen.
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra de mercaderías, como ser comestibles, bebidas, y otros para el abastecimiento de su local. Agradece a la Fundación por la oportunidad que le da, ya que de obtener el crédito, este le será de mucha ayuda.
texts.en:
Communal bank Kuña Guapa has been in 5 lending cycles with Fundación Paraguaya. The members make sacrifices and fight on a daily basis in order to provide a better future, different from the reality in which they lived. Currently the group has 15 members and all of them work in an environment of respect, solidarity and, above all, responsibility.
Hermelinda owns a small grocery store. She reports that she has many customers from her neighborhood and surrounding areas and there is a lot of demand for all kinds of products. She says that she would like to expand her store so that her business can keep on growing and her customers can be more comfortable. She says that everything she does is for the well-being of her family and of those who depend on her.
She requests this loan in order to purchase goods such as foodstuffs, beverages, etc. to stock up her store. She thanks the Fundación for the opportunity she is given, because getting the loan will be a big help.

loans.use: to purchase foodstuffs, beverages and other goods to stock up her store.

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet lives in the Nakulabye neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has four children, all of whom are in school. Annet lives in a home that she rents. She has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.   

Annet has a business of a retail shop. She has been in this business for over 10 years, and she works six days out of every week.   

Annet sells her products from home, by means of retail. She has requested a loan of 200,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of sugar and small jerycans of cooking oil.  

The main business challenges for Annet include seasonality and the increased prices of sugar and other commodities in Uganda. Her aspirations for her business are to be a wholesaler and to build her own house.

loans.use: To buy more bags of sugar and small jerrycans of cooking oil.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence lives in Uganda. She is single and has two children, both of whom are in school. Florence has a medical clinic. She has been in this business for three years, and she works six days out of every week. Florence sells her products from home, by means of retail. Florence has requested for a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more boxes of syrups and other tablets. 

The main business challenges for Florence include defaulters and thieves. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a fully stocked pharmacy. Florence lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and has access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent, school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of syrups and tablets

loans.name: Priscila

texts.en:
Priscilla is a married woman with six children, all of whom graduated from school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is the cost of purchasing seeds for farming. 

For the past ten years, she has operated a retail shop business, selling from home to neighbors and passersby. Her major challenge is delayed payments by those who purchase goods on credit. Priscilla dreams of expanding her business in the future. 

With the 20,000 Kenyan Shillings (KES) she wants to purchase sacks of beans, maize, and sugar. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of beans, maize, and sugar.

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en:
Mohamed is 43 years old, married, and has two children ages two and three. He runs a hotel and restaurant in Kissy near Freetown. He has one employee working with him. He also takes care of two relatives as well as his immediate family. 

Mohamed has been in this business for 21 years and sells food, drinks, and hosts his customers at his hotel and restaurant. He also earns income from renting out a house. He says that the main challenges to his business are the  supply of electrical power and inflation. 

He requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more drinks, a fan, and a freezer. Mohamed says that the extra income from this loan will help him build more structures and expand his business. In the future, he would like to expand into more branches of hotels and restaurants.

loans.use: To purchase drinks, a fan, stout, beer, a freezer, and food.

loans.name: Chicas Lindas Group

texts.es:
El comité denominado Chicas Lindas es D. la ciudad D. San Lorenzo, ellas son 15 mujeres, vecinas y amigas D. esa ciudad, que se unieron con el propósito D. generar mayores ingresos para sus hijos y familiares. Ellas son muy reconocidas en la zona por su trabajo en ayuda a la comunidad. Desean un desarrollo para cada una D. ellas, no solo en lo económico, sino también en lo personal.
La señora Ruth se dedica a la venta D. cosméticos, el cual le produce buenos ingresos. Comenta que tiene mucha clientela, pues las mujeres D. hoy en día siempre buscan verse bien, por lo que opto por este trabajo, ya que ve mucho futuro en el. Uno D. sus sueños es poder tener una tienda, donD. no solo pueda vender los cosméticos, sino también otros artículos para damas.
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra D. cosmético, lo cual le servirá para poder cumplir con los pedidos D. sus clientas. Está muy esperanzada en el crédito, ya que D. obtenerlo le será D. mucha ayuda.
texts.en:
The committee named "Chicas Lindas" ("The Pretty Girls") is in the city of San Lorenzo.  They are 15 women who are friends and neighbors from this city,  who meet together with the goal of generating greater income for their children and relatives.  They are very well-known in the area for their work helping the community.  They want each one of them to develop, not only financially, but also on a personal level.

Señora Ruth works selling cosmetics, which earns her a good income.  She comments that she has a good customer base, as women today are always looking to look good.  This is why she opted for this line of work, as she saw a good future in it.  One of her dreams is to have a store where she doesn't only sell cosmetics, but also other articles for women.

She is requesting the loan for the purchase of cosmetics, which will allow her to meet her customers' orders.  She is very hopeful about this loan, as getting it will be a great help to her.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics for subsequent sale.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine lives in Uganda.  She is single and has 3 children, all of whom are in school. Christine has a business of a retail shop. She has been in this business for 3 years, and she works 6 days out of every week.  

Christine has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO.   She will use the loan to buy more boxes of soap, bags of sugar and cartons of salt.  She also generates additional income through a motorcycle for hire.  The main business challenges for Christine include defaulters and thieves.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a fully stocked shop and also to be a wholesaler.  

Christine lives in a home that she rents.   She has access to electricity and to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more  bags of sugar, boxes of soap and cartons of salt

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Jesca

texts.en:
Jesca lives in  Uganda.  She is single and has 2 children, neither of whom is in school.  She also takes care of additional family members (grand children).  Jesca  has a business selling fruits and vegetables.  She has been in this business for 5 years, and she works 6 days out of every week.   Jesca sells her products in a shop. 

Jesca has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, with which she will buy more boxes of tomatoes, oranges and onions.  The main business challenges for Jesca include defaulters and thieves.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to be a wholesaler and also to build her own house.  

Jesca lives in a home that she rents.  She has access to electricity and to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of tomatoes, oranges and onions

loans.name: Benson

texts.en:
Benson is 26 years old.  He is married to Beatrice, who is a farmer.  They are blessed with one child, aged eight months.  Benson has been operating a motor cycle transport for the past two years, with a monthly income of KES 10,000 which he uses to support his family.

He is applying for his first loan with KADET LTD, after being introduced by a KADET staff member.  Benson will use the loan to buy another motorbike, which will increase his income. 

With the anticipated profit form the business, he will service his motorbike.  His hopes and dreams are to buy a commercial taxi which will provide for his child’s education.

loans.use: To buy another motorbike.

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
Simon is an enterprising  48 year-old  businessman.  He is married to Mary, who is a businesswoman. They are blessed with two children, aged ten and eight years, respectively.  He has been selling vehicle spare parts for the past six years, with the monthly income of KES 15,000 which he uses to support his family.

He is applying for his second loan with KADET, after repaying the previous loan successfully. Simon will use the loan to buy vehicle spare parts. 

With the anticipated profit from the business, he will expand his spare parts shop. His hopes and dreams are to open a car assembly shop, which will provide for his family needs.

loans.use: To buy vehicle spare parts

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is 50 years old.  He is a mixed crop farmer, and is married to Judy, who is also a farmer. They are blessed with two children, aged 25 and 23 years, respectively.  He has been a farmer for the past ten years, with a monthly income of KES 12,000, which he uses to support his family members.


He is applying for his first loan with KADET after being introduced by an existing KADET customer.  Samuel will use the loan to buy seedlings and fertilizer for his farm.  With the anticipated profit from the business, he will educate his children up to university level. 


His hopes and dreams are to venture into greenhouse farming and keep dairy cows, which will improve the living standard of his family.

loans.use: To buy seedlings and fertilizer for his farm.

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Anna  lives in Kampala, Uganda.  She is married, with 4 children.  Three of them go to school. She sells green bananas and tomatoes at the market.  She has been in business for the last 4 years. She works seven days a week. Her other source of income is selling piped water from home.  

She has requested a loan of 200,000 from MCDT SACCO to buy more bunches of bananas and boxes of tomatoes.  Anna's business challenges include the rainy season and thieves  Her inspirational goal is to educate her children and also to see her business grow big.  She lives in her own house where her family has access to piped water and electricity. Her monthly expenses include power and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas and boxes of tomatoes

loans.name: Buena Fe Group

texts.es:
El comité Buena Fe nace hace más de tres años mediante la gestión y el apoyo de otro comité que se encontraba trabajando en dicho lugar. Este comité es de la ciudad de San Lorenzo, en estos más de dos años de intenso trabajo han crecido tanto social como económicamente, son reconocidas en el lugar como mujeres muy trabajadoras.
La señora Alva se dedica a la venta de ropas de todo tipo, comenta que tiene muchos clientes ya que siempre tiene muchas variedades, este trabajo le genera buenos ingresos, los cuales la ayudan en la manutención de la casa. Dice que todo trabajo es poco para darle a su familia todo lo que ella merece. Uno de sus sueños es abrir una tienda para poder exhibir mejor sus productos.
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra de prendas de estación, como ser camperas, poleras, y guantes, lo cual le servirá para poder abastecer su stock de mercaderías. Agradece a la Fundación por la oportunidad que esta le da.
texts.en:
The “Buena Fe” (Good Faith) committee was born over three years ago thanks to the initiative and support of another committee that was working in that place.  This committee is from the city of San Lorenzo.  In these more than two years of intensive work they have grown both socially and economically.  They are well known in the place for being very hardworking women.

Alva sells all sorts of clothes.  She comments that she has many customers because she always has a lot of variety.  This work generates good income which helps her support her household.  She says that all her hard work is the least she can do to give her family everything they deserve.  One of her dreams is to open a store to display her products better.

She is asking for the loan to buy seasonal items like jackets, t-shirts and gloves which will help her stock up on merchandise.  She is grateful to the Fundación for the opportunity it gives her.

loans.use: to buy winter clothes for resale.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice has been operating her salon business for the last eighteen years in Kenyatta market, Nairobi city. She is 40 years old and married to Morris. They have four children.

She was introduced to KADET LTD by a friend who is also a KADET client. This is will be her first loan. She has requested KES.50,000.  She intends to use the loan to buy shampoo, hair relaxer and hair extensions.  In the future, Beatrice hopes to expand her business and open another salon.

loans.use: To buy shampoo, hair relaxer and hair pieces.

loans.name: Hawah

texts.en:
Hawah lives in Kampala, Uganda.  She is married, with 3 children.  One of her children goes to school.   She sells charcoal from home on a retail basis.  She has been in business for the last 4 years. She works seven day a week.  

She has requested a loan of 200,000 from MCDT SACCO to buy more bags of charcoal and matooke.  Her major challenge is transportation. Her goal is to educate her children up to university level and also to sell at wholesale only.   She lives in her own house and her family has access to piped water and electricity. Her monthly expenses are power and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick is a 66 year-old mixed crop farmer.  He is widowed, with two adult children, ages forty and thirty six years.  He has been farming for the past year, with a monthly income of KES 10,000, which he uses to provide for his basic needs.

He is applying for his second loan from KADET after repaying the previous loan successfully.  Patrick will use the loan to buy seedlings and manure for his farm.  With the anticipated profit from the business he will buy a dairy cow.  His hopes are to open a butchery shop and stop farming.

loans.use: To buy seedlings and manure for his farm.

loans.name: Aureliano

texts.es:
Don Aureliano  tiene 56 años de edad, está casado hace más de 29 años con la Señora Lucila de 48 años de edad, tienen juntos 4 hijos todos ya mayores de edad.
El señor Aureliano es hijo de un agricultor, creció en una de las compañías de Carapeguá, trabajó en el campo con su padre. A los 26 años de edad se casó con su señora quién es hija de una tejedora y  empezaron a trabajar juntos. Hoy ya hace más de 20  años que se dedica a la venta de las tradicionales sobrecamas y hamacas que lleva a vender por  zonas de Itapúa y ciudad del Este. Cuenta con una clientela bien formada, incluso su señora, quien es artesana, elabora las frazadas y así le sale más barato. Gracias a este trabajo y al esfuerzo de los dos pudieron construir una linda casa y también comprarse una camioneta, la cual utiliza para repartir sus productos y a la vez puede brindar a su familia una vida honrada y digna.
